author: {'steamid': '76561198355254907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4739, 'last_played': 1607089569}
review:
Pineview Drive is a very well made game with decent graphics, awesome game mechanisms, a mystery to solve and a strange ending. The rustling in the bushes while outside is a bit much in the earlier levels when the scarecrow is inactive. I find that througout the game It's like a scavenger hunt for keys to open doors in order to proceed. I find the jumpscares impressive and I find the presence of light from candles and flashlight greatly reduces ghostly encounters, as for that cackling laughing clown doll and other slight spooks you need to walk slow and not move your mouse so it doesn't affect your sanity bar. 
I was able to beat the Scarecrow-The Eight Letters side game after beating the main game, which reminds me alot of Slenderman, and it took me about 20+ trys to finally beat the Scarecrow side game.
Overall, I would highly recommend this game.

-THEORY-  +  -SPOILER ALERT-

The bunker underneath the cemetary could have possibly been a Nazi research laboratory during WWII and they dabbled into the paranormal which would explain the haunted house and the doll. Also, on the last level in the one of the bunkers rooms you encounter lots of still working radio equipment in a room that resemble WWII radio communication equipment that is still running after at least 20+ years plus the machine rooms.
There is a room in the bunker that deals with surgical proceedings including a vision of a child crying being trapped inside of a chest trying to escape, as well as a room full of beds covered in blood indicating there were test subjects, or victims.
The giant machine you have to activate at the very end may or may not have something to do with opening rifts to different dimensions or periods of time in the past/future.
Because once you power it on you see a glimpse of your wife, yeah it's confusing.

The Nazis have been rumered to be obsessed with the paranormal and the occult, as well as develop sophisticated machinery that binds this reality with the spirit world, and more.
Also, the mansion is pretty old, old enough to be pre-WWII.
And the main character came back 20 years later.
It's just my theory, tell me what you think, if anybody happens to stumble upon my post.

- END OF THEORY-

-ANOTHER SPOILER-

It is possible that the main character killed his wife 20 years ago after looking at the haunted doll in the end scene. 

-END SPOILER-

UPDATE:

There are a couple of cons, one for the main game, the other con for the Scarecrow-The Eight Letters side game.

1st con:
After completing the main game and wish to play it a second time, all the 30 days are unlocked so if you play part of the game and exit it, it still saves, but unless you write down the day on paper or you have a good memory, the game doesn't indicate on the load screen where you left off and just shows all 30 days. I restarted the game about three times.
i would suggest playing the game all the way through, or minimizing the game and putting your computer to sleep to maximize and resume later.

2nd con:
As for the Scarecrow game, if you find one of the letters on the bench beside the front main enterance of the mansion you cannot pick it up and need to start over. This is a bug.
I tried reporting a bug with a screenshot on Steam Issues section regarding the Scarecrow letter on the bench being unable to be picked up.

review: The game is stupid dark in the house. Lights barely light up any area and even at maximum brightness you can't see anything in the dark areas. It's very frustrating because the little sounds and ambiance do seem like it could be a decent spooky game. However, when you're squinting at your computer screen because you can't find a door handle (half the time wondering if you are even looking at a door), it just feels annoying and like you might strain your eyes. If they can fix the brightness/contrast issue, I'll look in on this title again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997678124', 'num_games_owned': 1626, 'num_reviews': 443, 'playtime_forever': 2136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2083, 'last_played': 1543859898}
review:
This review is loooooooooooooooooooong overdue. :P 

After just over 30 hours of playtime and several playthroughs, I can safely say that I would recommend this to other people. The price tag is a little high for it's age(4 years). It should probably be sold for closer to $5-10. Buy this on sale and keep your eyes peeled for the sequel!! 

This game isn't for everybody. 

If you don't like 'walking simulators', jump scares, or back tracking: You're gonna have a bad time. 

If you do enjoy these things, then proceed! :) 

I'll start with the things that bothered me first.

1. It's DARK!! Oh man, it is really freaking dark! I kinda cheated and set my monitor to the nighttime setting and didn't need to rely so heavily on my flashlight. Which is nice because when that thing goes out, if you don't have any batteries, you are totally hosed and will have an impossible time feeling your way throught the pitch darkness.

2. Buggy fear mechanic. The game determines whether or not you were 'scared' by how much your mouse moves when it launches a jump scare at you. This was frustrating as I have naturally twitchy movements since I'm always on high-alert while playing spooky games. It doesn't mean I'm scared, but the game still punishes me for turning to look at the thing that jumped out by reducing my health. Luckily, wandering around seems to cause it to regen, albeit very slowly. It kinda took some of the enjoyment out of the game to have to keep my hand off my mouse while wandering the halls or entering rooms. It makes exploring harder when you can't look around without the game thinking you've been frightened. 

3. The ending. Without spoilers: Like many of the people who played the game, I was kinda left hanging by the ending. You spend a couple hours working your way through the story and then you're left with a sort of confusing and underwhelming end. I dunno. With how much went into the rest of the game, it just felt tacked on without much thought. 

Ok! Now on to what I DID like :D

1. The atmosphere! It is so spooky! I love being creeped out and really enjoyed taking my time to wander the halls and experience all the strange sounds and scares that the house had to offer. There is a clown. You have been warned. :P

2. The Story(until the end). Up until the end, I really enjoyed the story! It was very eerie and had me wanting to explore deeper and open all the doors like a macabre little advent calendar(if you've never had an advent calendar, you are missing out!!) with treats to find in all the openings. 

3. Exploration. Ok, take this with a grain of salt because you hardly ever leave the house. But this place is HUGE! If you enjoy poking around in every little nook and cranny for things, you'll enjoy this as much as I did. The back tracking was a little rough in some of the later levels, but I still had fun.

That's it! I enjoyed and even loved the game. I'm looking forward to the sequel when it drops. 

Love, peace, and chicken grease. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198020707297', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1408009552}
review:
The biggest reason this game gets a ten thumbs down from me is because there is no focus on any kind of story.
Originally you arte supposedt to find out what happened to your lost wife twenty years ago.
Hmmm intriguing I want to know more...
Then thirty nights of nothing to do with that.
Every night has nothing to do with any story arc or what happened before.
It's find the keys to a new jump scare for the night then repeat.
Then the last night you are in a creepy underground bunker you entered through a grave and finish with trying to turn on some wierd machinery. You have the promise of a satisfying ending at least then...
Then a flash of light and blurry running through woods.
I woke up and it was all a dream.

Second reason, Granted there are some genuinely chilling moments, but all sense of urgency, exploring , horror  even jump jump scares is thrown out the window when you realise nothing is trying to hurt you or chase you. It's just creepy, like the same clown doll turning up in different rooms.

Third reason it is so dark, you have to put the gamma up all the way to see anything. It feels to me like its a cheap trick by the developers to try to make it scary.

It's really more a walking simulator which loses its way to pointlessness

Fourth reason, worst ending ever

author: {'steamid': '76561197990925811', 'num_games_owned': 4288, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1540792658}
review:
-Good morning sir, name's Peter Parker.
-Hiya kid, know how a warden works?
-Frankly, not that much, sir. I have little experience.
-Well, more or less you simply have to check every room on every day and check if something is strange.
-(sounds like fun...) It seems easy.
-Let's go in.
-My..this place is huge, does every door look the same?
-Yep, huge discount on Black Friday when it was remodeled, every key is identical too, same story.
-That could be troublesome, do you have some kind of map or something to help me out a bit when walking around?
-Nah, there was but I catched a bad cold last month and had no tissues near, think of it like playing those cool Amiga's dungeon crawler games and make your own on paper, cool dont'ya think?
-(Amiwhat?) Ah..yeah, I'll make a workaround. With the keys that can't be much of a chore.
-Ha, then you will find this funny: this place is full of pesky poltergeist and they stole most of the keys so I cannot give them to ya.
-Oh, I'll try to find them while I'm....
-Also, I had already locked every door as I was leaving so you will have to search for those keys actively in order to check da house. 
-Ok, that's annoying but they will be for sure in a closet or...
-The ghosts are harmless, don't be afraid, but they like pranks. I'm sure they're gonna lend ya the keys one by one at slow pace with notorious jumpscares.
-(I'm starting to get pissed)  ) No problemo.
-You must know they appear at random so you have to walk aimlessly until you find [strike]the  script trigger[/strike] the spot they are.
-(that's directly obnoxious, glad I have my spider sense which triggers if I'm wandering for 5-10 minutes and points me to a paranormal event that I won't have any clue it's happening, maybe even in other floors)
-Did ya catch all?
-Yes sir, frankly this seems more problematic than I thought but I need the job.
-Good, see ya in a month kid.
-Wait, a month? I was told the job would last no more than 2 weeks! Do I have to do the same (crap) cleaning over 30 times?
-Sorry but winter season is longer this year, climatic change and all I guess, they should have told you that. You will have plenty of time to prepare your thesis or the thing you students do these days though.
-(this is bullshit, you're going to hear me when I'm back, May) I'll have to accept that, thank you very much for your counseling.
-It's nothing kid, try to have fun.
-Oh, excuse me sir, what is that piece of paper over there?
-That? Don't worry, my nephew was writing a bland overused script for a cheap Netflix's Halloween movie that was rejected, that can't be more of 3,4 paragraphs in total. Feel free to collect them if you get bored.
-(that could be the rewarding experience I'm looking for while I'm stuck here in the middle of nowhere freezing my butt with abhorrent and unpleasent repetitive tasks) Is it any good sir?
-HAHAHA, let me give you some advice kid: life always punches twice. The answer is no.

review: Yeah, I'm gonna have to side with the people who can't get past the tedious game play and the BS "fear awareness". Too much reliance on jump scares. Zero use of brainpower to accomplish anything - it would have been so much better if there was any connection at all between the pages and the game, but there was none. Just every day, wander the house, trying doors, hoping to either come across some random jump scare that might produce a key, or else get a hint from the game that oh, that sound means I need to visit a particular area. When I realized that I was googling ways to just get through each day and maybe get the achievements, I understood that this was over for me. Too bad, I adore haunted houses.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997631644', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1526958423}
review:
Pineview Drive oder "Wie werde ich grau in einer Nacht".


Zu allererst: Cyria ist Schuld!


Story:
Die Geschichte ist schnell erz√§hlt. 20 Jahre zuvor ist die Ehefrau des Protagonisten auf dem Grundst√ºck des Pineview Drive Manor verschwunden. Nun ist der Held zur√ºckgekehrt, um den Verbleib seiner Liebsten aufzukl√§ren. Notizen aus der Vergangenheit sollen ihm dabei helfen, seine Erinnerungen aufzufrischen.


Gameplay:
Pineview Drive ist kein Survival Horror. Das Spiel zelebriert die Langsamkeit und den gen√ºsslichen Grusel. Wer also erwartet, mit der Pumpgun im Anschlag an jeder Ecke einen Zombie wegbratzen zu k√∂nnen, ist hier definitiv falsch. Die Anzeigen im Spiel sind minimalistisch gehalten, oben links gibt es einen, ich nenne es mal, Gesundheitsbalken. Oben rechts z√§hlt eine simple Strichanzeige die noch verf√ºgbaren Streichh√∂lzer und Taschenlampenbatterien. Erstere dienen dazu, im ganzen Haus verteilte Kerzen anzuz√ºnden, letztere betreiben nat√ºrlich die Taschenlampe, mit der man auch dunkle Ecken ausleuchten kann. Die Anzeigen sind gut erkennbar, ohne dabei zu dominant oder gar ablenkend zu sein. 

Zusammen spenden beide ein wenig Licht im dunklen Heim. An dieser Stelle muss ich manchem Kritiker widersprechen, zu keinem Zeitpunkt hatte ich das Gef√ºhl, das Spiel sei zu dunkel oder es g√§be zu wenig Nachschub. Wirklich im Dunkeln stand ich zu keiner Zeit. Wer nat√ºrlich wie von Sinnen beim ersten schwindenden Balken die Taschenlampe neu best√ºckt, k√∂nnte sp√§ter Probleme kriegen.

Mit diesen Leuchtmitteln ausgestattet erkundet man nun das alte Herrenhaus. Dummerweise sieht die Hausverwaltung nur das Schlimmste im Menschen und hat daher pr√§ventiv so gut wie alle T√ºren verschlossen. Man tappert also durch die dunklen R√§umlichkeiten (die Sonne verschwindet regelm√§√üig schneller als die Hoffnung der Niederlande auf eine WM-Teilnahme) und sucht nach Schl√ºsseln, Hinweisen und ultimativ, nach einer 20 Jahre alten Notiz. Jede Notiz beendet einen von insgesamt 30 Tagen.

Ist es anfangs noch recht einfach, den √úberblick √ºber die besuchten und noch verschlossenen R√§ume zu erhalten, wird dies mit zunehmender Spieldauer und steigender Anzahl an freigeschalteten Zimmer immer schwieriger, bis man sich irgendwann an die Zeit im Schullandheim erinnert f√ºhlt, wo man nach dem n√§chtlichen Klogang wegen zuviel Limo versucht, sein 4-Personen-Hochbettzimmer zu finden. Gl√ºcklicherweise sind die Entwickler gn√§dig und wenn man lange genug ziellos und verzweifelt umhergewandert ist, gibt die Spielfigur einen hilfreichen Hinweis.

Der Horror im Spiel selbst entsteht dabei weniger durch eine "reale" Bedrohung, als vielmehr durch das st√§ndige Gef√ºhl des "Was-k√∂nnte-passieren?". Untermalt und verst√§rkt wird dies durch eine hervorragende Soundkulisse (mehr dazu unter Sound).

Regelm√§√üige Autosaves und die Tipps des Protagonisten haben daf√ºr gesorgt, dass ich zu keiner Zeit das Gef√ºhl hatte, das Spiel w√§re unfair oder unschaffbar. Man kann sich also ganz dem gepflegten Gusel hingeben. Inwiefern die spielinterne "Angsterkennung" nun gut oder schlecht funktioniert, kann ich kaum ohne einen detailierten Einblick in die Engine beurteilen. Ich kann lediglich sagen, dass die Jumpscares mich ein paar Mal ziemlich aufgepeitscht haben. Job erf√ºllt.


Grafik:
Die Grafik ist h√ºbsch und ausreichend zweckm√§√üig. Man darf auch nicht vergessen, dass das Spiel Stichtag 23.05.2018 fast 4 Jahr auf dem Buckel hat. Trotzdem gibt es immer noch sch√∂ne Momente, wenn in der Nacht die Gewitterblitze scharf umrissene Schatten in die Landschaft zeichnen. Charme gewinnen die Zimmer des Herrenhauses durch die zum Teil sehr aufwendige Verzierung mit Details. Mein pers√∂nliches Mini-Highlight sind die vielen Gem√§lde im Spiel, die mir mehr als einmal die Frage in den Kopf schickte, ob einer der Grafiker das Foto-Album seiner Ururgro√ümutter gepl√ºndert hat.


Sound:
Meiner Meinung nach einer der Must-Have-Gr√ºnde f√ºr dieses Spiel. Sind es zu Beginn noch die ganzen typischen Ger√§usche, die ein altes Haus im Wald am A***h der Welt macht, so werden diese mehr und mehr erg√§nzt durch Dinge, von denen man einfach wei√ü, dass sie nicht in dieses Haus geh√∂ren (Stichwort Gunni und Herbert). Es f√§ngt an zu rascheln, knarren, knarzen, T√ºren schlagen zu, Schritte ert√∂nen, es wird w√ºst gehechelt...kurz und gut, der Sound jagt einem ein ums andere Mal einen Schauer √ºber den R√ºcken. Ich empfehle an dieser Stelle eine gute Anlage oder ein 7.1-Headset.
Der gute Soundtrack tut sein √ºbriges dazu und peitscht einen so manches Mal regelrecht auf, bevorzugt, wenn es gar keine Bedrohung gibt. Der n√§chste Jumpscare knallt dann durchaus mal gerne in die entspannende Ruhe danach.


Bedienbarkeit:
Das Spiel l√§uft fl√ºssig und das bei moderaten Anforderungen. Zum Steuern ben√∂tigt man lediglich WASD und drei Aktionstasten. Die Maus dient zum Umschauen. Es gibt keine M√∂glichkeit, zu springen, sprinten oder sonstige Spielereien zu veranstalten. Was im ersten Moment minimalistisch erscheint, erweist sich langfristig als Segen, da das Spiel ohnehin nicht auf Speedruns oder schnelles durchhecheln ausgelegt ist.


Fazit:
Pineview Drive ist derzeit f√ºr rund 20‚Ç¨ auf Steam zu haben. Das Durchspielen der Hauptstory hat mich knapp 7 1/2 Stunden gekostet (und gef√ºhlt etliche Lebensjahre). Jedem, der Gefallen findet an einem intensiven Gruselgef√ºhl, lege ich es ans Herz, diesem kleinen Sch√§tzchen eine Chance zu geben. Wer auf ein Ballerspiel a la Dead Space hofft, ist hier definitiv fehl am Platz. Doch Spieler, die ein Alien: Isolation vor allem wegen der Atmosph√§re geliebt haben, sollten dringend auch mal einen Blick auf Pineview Drive werfen.

Und an meinen grauen Haaren sind das Spiel und Cyria schuld.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114719077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1523907594}
review:
Pineview Drive ist das bisher beste Spiel von VIS-Games!

Es √ºberzeugt durch eine echt beklemmende Atmosph√§re, gepaart mit einer furchtbar gruseligen Ger√§uschkulisse. Auch die Jumpscares (und davon gibt es viele) sind gut platziert und jagen auch dem Hartgesottensten noch einen Schrecken ein. Ich habs bisher viele Horrorspiele spielen d√ºrfen und f√ºr mich ist das gruseligste bisher ganz klar dieses Spiel. 
Die Story f√ºhrt uns anfangs zu einem Haus, das eher einem Labyrinth √§hnelt. Wir wollen herausfinden, was mit unserer Frau Linda passiert und das gestaltet sich schwerer als gedacht, denn nicht nur das riesengro√üe Haus will uns in die Irre f√ºhren, auch die weiteren Mitbewohner des Haues wollen uns von diesem Vorhaben abhalten.

Das Gameplay ist simpel und wiederholt sich oft. Wir m√ºssen 30 Tage im Haus √ºberleben und sammeln dazu jeden Tag Informationen, was passiert ist - damit wollen wir anscheinend unser Ged√§chtnis auffrischen. Jeden Tag durchstreifen wir das Haus und sammeln Batterien, Streichh√∂lzer und einen Zettel, der den Tag beendet. Dies kann auf Dauer f√ºr den einen oder anderen mit Sicherheit sehr langweilig werden. Der Protagonist hilft einem jedoch, wenn man zu lange nach dem St√ºck Papier sucht und nicht weiter kommt. Finde dieses Feature sehr gut, denn es hat auch mir sehr oft aus der Klemme geholfen.

Minuspunkte muss ich f√ºr das Angsterkennungssystem geben, denn es erkennt nicht wirklich die Angst, sondern eine falsche Bewegung, die man bei Erschreckern macht - ob man sich nun erschreckt hat oder nicht. Man muss erst verstehen, was dieses System ausl√∂st, bevor man dagegen steuern kann. Bis dahin kann man aber durchaus schon einmal Game Over gegangen sein.
Den gr√∂√üten Kritikpunkt habe ich an der Helligkeit des Spiels. Nat√ºrlich bekommt man Batterien bereit gestellt, doch sobald diese leer sind, sieht man leider nur noch sehr wenig in dem Spiel. Auch auf der h√∂chsten Helligkeitseinstellung ist das Spiel noch viel zu dunkel. Und wieso muss die Taschenlampe bereits ab zwei Strichen anfangen zu flackern und arg dunkel werden? Sehr schade. Das hat mich beim Spielen wirklich sehr gest√∂rt.

Ansonsten ist dieses Spiel ganz klasse f√ºr mich gewesen und ich bin froh, dass ich auf die Empfehlungen vieler geh√∂rt habe, die dieses Spiel bereits gespielt haben! Freue mich schona uf den 2. Teil! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1523748917}
review:
Tags: Adventure - WS - Walking Sim
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Keyfetch walking sim with daynight cycle. Have to wait inordinate amount of time for daylight to get anywhere. Too dark. Every door locked with pointless keyfetch.

You get a thirty day time limit and most of everything you do involve finding and flipping light switches that barely light up the environment and lighting up candlesticks. The occasional key will allow you to backtrack and open a new room, which will in turn, contain either another key, or matches lightswitches and batteries. Not sure where the flashlight is and probably not worth playing until you find it.

There is a vague backstory of murders a long time ago or disappearances, pretty standard horror walksim stuff. 

The engine looked half decent and the layout of the manor was not inuinteresting to explore so it is kind of a shame that the game has you twiddle thumbs for so long without any way to fast forward the time.

You can tell the game knows about the waiting aspect in how it lays clocks all over the manor for you to keep track of it, still, it makes for poor gameplay.

Conclusion: Not worth keeping around in permanent library. I assume that you have to somehow unlock all the doors by the 30th day time limit or face some kind of game over. There was also some health bar type gauge which I can only presume represents sanity and possibly gets lowered when you trigger jumpscare scripts by fumbling around in the dark due to impatience. Removed for declutter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078982721', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1442607265}
review:
Schade, meine Erwartung, dass es sich bei Pineview Drive um ein neues Scratches handeln k√∂nnte, wurde leider nicht erf√ºllt. Das Spiel enth√§lt einige gute Ans√§tze, die aber nicht konsequent zu Ende gedacht und umgesetzt wurden. So h√§tte die Entwickler beispielsweise selbst darauf kommen m√ºssen, dass es auf Dauer wenig motivierend sein kann, st√§ndig Schl√ºssel zu suchen und anschlie√üend Unmengen verschlossener T√ºren abzuklappern. Das Spielprinzip tr√§gt einfach nicht, erst recht nicht √ºber 8 bis 10 Spielstunden. Und das Ende der "Geschichte" ist v√∂llig unbefriedigend. So kann es nicht weiter √ºberraschen, dass es kaum je ein Mensch l√§nger als 30 Tage im Haus am Pineview Drive ausgehalten hat.

PRO:
- einige gelungene Scare-Jumps
- akzeptabler Sound
- Bedienung geht leicht von der Hand
- ordentlicher Umfang (plus Zusatz-Modi)

CONTRA:
- Schock-Effekte wiederholen sich sehr schnell
- eint√∂nige Schl√ºssel- und T√ºren-Suche
- Story bleibt nebens√§chlich
- m√§√üige Grafik
- nahezu g√§nzlicher Verzicht auf R√§tsel
- kaum M√∂glichkeiten der Interaktion
- entt√§uschendes Ende

author: {'steamid': '76561197995450085', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1682367891}
review:
Obwohl ich das Spiel schon aus einem LP vor einiger Zeit kannte, habe mich entschlossen, diese Spiel selber zu spielen, zumal es ja seit einiger Zeit die Version 2.1 gibt, die ich noch nicht kannte und ich auch einiges schon aus dem LP vergessen hatte.

Kurz gesagt, ich liebe diesen Titel. Warum?
Es ist ein Spiel, was mit den unterschiedlichen Arten Horror arbeitet - Jumpscares, atmosph√§risch subtiler Horror und Psychoterror. Besonders mag ich den Ansatz, dass nichts in dem Spiel einen umbringen kann, au√üer man l√§sst sich im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes von der eigenen Angst besiegen.
Bereits am Ersten der dreizig Tage schafft es das Spiel, mich in seine gruselige Atmosph√§re reinzuziehen. Neben den mysteri√∂sen Haus selbst, sind es vorallem die Ger√§usche und die Musik, die mich oft erschaudern lassen. Von Tag zu Tag steigert das Spiele immer mehr den psychischen Druck und h√§lt fast immer neue √úberraschungen parat. Denn neben den t√§glichen, geskripteten Events, um neue Schl√ºssel zu erhalten, werden immer mehr Zufallsereignisse und auch station√§re Gegenst√§nde zum Leben erweckt. Gerade die Zufallseffekte haben mich teilweise heftig erschrocken, obwohl ich ein paar davon aus der Grundversion schon kannte.

Obwohl ich das Spiel sehr gerne zocke, kann ich auch andere Spieler verstehen, denen der Titel weniger zusagt. Denn das Gameplay ist tats√§chlich sehr simpel gehalten. 90 Prozent des Spiels ist man wirklich nur damit besch√§ftigt durch das Haus zu wandeln, Schl√ºssel und Notizen zu suchen und damit das Haus und dessen Vergangenheit zu erkunden. Komplexe R√§tsel und actionlastige Szenen fehlen hier komplett. Wer sowas sucht, wird es das bei diesen Titel vermissen und sich aus herausfordernder Sicht langweilen.

Auch die Story ist eher vage und im Hintergrund gehalten und ich als Spieler hatte diesbez√ºglich am Ende mehr Fragen als Antworten. Das muss an sich nicht schlecht sein - das macht es nur noch mysteri√∂ser. Wenn man allerdings am Ende sich eher eine Aufl√∂sung w√ºnscht, wird hier entt√§uscht.

Um zum Gameplay noch positive Aspekte zu erw√§hnen - das Spiel hat auch ein Hilfesystem. Denn der Protagonist gibt einem Hinweise, wenn man das n√§chste Event nach einer angemessenen Zeitspanne nicht gefunden hat.
Technisch lief das Spiel bei mir einwandfrei bzw. wenn es Bugs in der Version gab, haben die sich g√§nzlich aus meiner Wahrnehmung entzogen. Auch das Angsterkennungsystem hat bei mir gut funktioniert.

Untern Strich kann ich sagen:
Wenn man sich einfach mal in eine heftig gruselige Umgebung reinziehen lassen und sich ordentlich erschrecken lassen will und dabei wenig Gameplay braucht (weil man vielleicht nervlich eh schon komplett damit besch√§ftigt ist die Atmosph√§re auszuhalten), ist es ideal aus meiner Sicht. Es ist nicht f√ºr jeden etwas dabei, aber das, was da Spiel bietet ist sehr gut gelungen. F√ºr mich war es genau das Richtige.
√úber einen Nachfolger, w√ºrde ich mich sehr freuen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005879531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1516950687}
review:
I like the concept of a haunted mansion game, but this one just doesn't work for me.  The game claims to be aware of your fear but in my experience the game doesn't care if you react at all, it just takes away health for the fun of taking away health.  

Stop to look out a window and notice a swing set in the yard?  Gotcha!  Lose some health!
Pick up some batteries from a table?  Gotcha!  Lose some health!
Check out the wallpaper?  Gotcha!  Lose some health!
Walk back outside to check your car's license plate?  Gotcha!  Lose some health!

I guess those are some of the deepest fears I'm facing in this spine chilling adventure?  Walking into a room and finding the furniture had been moved around?  That's not terrifying.  I'm married.  That's how life is.  The feeling you're looking for is resignation.   

You want to scare someone?  Make us get the mail and find $22,127 in credit card bills we weren't expecting.  You can take some health away for that.  

Jokes aside, this game just didn't bring anything new.  No scare attempts I haven't seen dozens of times.  Everything was predictable.  Losing health for a "scare" just didn't work since I either wasn't anywhere near "the scare" or it wasn't a scare.  Makes it seem like random health loss, which makes it feel annoying.

review: Pineview Drive hat mich echt fertig gemacht im Stream :D Sobald ich es gestartet habe wurde ich total verkrampft und hatte nasse H√§nde. Die Atmosph√§re war echt bedr√ºckend und man wusste nie was als n√§chstes passiert. Das Haus ist exorbitant gro√ü, dunkel und mit vieeeeeeeelen T√ºren. Die Grafik ist stimmig mit Liebe zum Detail :3 Man wurde recht gut durch die Geschichte gef√ºhrt nur leider hat manchmal die lange Suche nach dem n√§chsten Schl√ºssel das ganze etwas ausgebremst. Mir hat es richtig gut gefallen denn ich habe gelitten und seit dem angst vor Linda *grins*

author: {'steamid': '76561198206068500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1658071451}
review:
Ein absolut schlechtes Horrorspiel!
Grottenschlechte Performace. Es l√§uft zwischen 24-43 FPS, was lustiger weise nicht an meinem PC liegt. Kleines Beispiel:
Ich spiele Resident Evil 7 und habe dort alles auf Hoch und es l√§uft irgendwo bei 50-70 FPS, bei Pineview Drive l√§uft es mit niedrigen Settings wie oben gesagt zwischen 24-43 FPS.
Dann kommen die Jumpscares. Nicht innovativ, geschweige denn gruselig.
Das gameplay besteht daraus NUR schl√ºssel zu suchen, um dann eine T√ºr zu √∂ffnen.
Das macht ihr 30 n√§chte lang, immer und immer wieder. Ich hatte das Spiel √ºbrigens bereits durch, nur hat man all meine Spielst√§nde gel√∂scht.
Wie dieses Spiel Positive Reviews bekommt ist mir echt ein R√§tzel.
Achso und die Texturen sind f√ºr ein Spiel von 2014 ziemlich h√§sslich. Wer also ein Spiel mit schlechter Performance, langweiligem Gameplay und nicht gruseligen Jumpscares haben will, der sollte f√ºr 20 verdammte Euro sofort zuschlagen. 
Alle anderen, die etwas gutes Spielen wollen, sollten was anderes im Store suchen, aber bitte Spart euch euer Geld und Kauft nicht dieses Spiel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069519208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1459048834}
review:
I genuinely love this game. The fear meter mechanic is unique, I really love the atmosphere, the mansion is insanely convoluted which is both a pro and a con, and the story is at least intriguing throughout the game.

But...

The lack of animation is disappointing, once you've opened up like 50+ rooms it may take you hours to find the right key, you eventually get used to the scares, and the ending leaves a lot to be desired. Truth be told, the ending is so disappointing it's hard to recommend this game, but I can't help but love it. I will say this game is definitely not for everyone, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046010361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1514447041}
review:
[ m i l d + s p o i l e r s ]

This game starts off promising.  You arrive at a spooky house and find many keys to unlock many doors to find notes that progress the story and advance time to the next day.  Each day is a "level."  It seems like this is how the game is going to work, but then you run out of keys.

So, you roam around the house aimlessly, checking every room you've checked before to trigger an "event" that unlocks a new key.  As the game goes on, one event is equivalent to one key, which is equivalent to one door.  This means roaming around the house, checking every door you can remember that is locked, and hoping said key unlocks that door.  

You can see how this would get tedious.

Not only that, but "events" don't trigger until they feel like it, in my experience.  This means you can theoretically enter the same room three times or so before an event occurs, leading to a lot of aimless wandering.  To counter this, after an indefinite amount of time has passed, the player character will offer the player a hint.

This means the optimal way to play is to sit in front of a clock or something and play Mario Run for half a world waiting for your character to tell you where to go.  

By this point, I was already invested in the game and how many doors I had unlocked, so I stuck with it.

I didn't mention it before, but there are RNG obstacles that "frighten" your character.  Each "fright" saps your health bar.  If your health bar reaches 0, you restart the level over again at full health.  This doesn't become important until way later into the game, where the encounters seems to pick up.

What prompted my to write this review is that the final level changes structure and requires the player to walk a (mostly) straight line for 5+ minutes.  What's annoying is that my character takes too much damage doing this and I die before I can complete the level.  This means I have to retrace my steps for 5+ minutes, and hope that RNG doesn't kill me.  It's fucking garbage.  Please don't do this again.

A lot of the tedium could be alleviated with a map, but I think that was intentionally left out of the game to induce disorientation.  

In that case, maybe lessen the amount of rooms, or make sure the path to each room is unique or has an interesting set piece.  To the game's credit, there is effort in designing many rooms to have a unique "look" in terms of decoration, but they could have gone further.  There is plenty of redundancy in hallway structure, for instance: three floors of the largely the same hallways, with each hallway having doors in similar places.

In any case, it's obvious the game's structure was meant to prolong game-time with some serious padding.  The "events" feel like a cheap way to move the player from day to day; and, I hadn't mentioned it, but earlier on, it's easy to miss a key due to how they can unintentionally blend into the environment.  Once it's understood that a key appears right at the site of an event, the flow of the game is marginally less tedious.

Another way the developer could have relieved tedium is to have the notes you pick up serve as a hint to where the player is supposed to go the next day.  Instead, your character will read about things days before he interacts with them, if at all.  

+Creepy atmosphere
+Interesting environment
+Unlocking doors is fun
+Exploring is fun
+Events can be scary!
+Good music at points
+Game doesn't crash
+Game progression never breaks

-Bad framerate
-Keys blend into environment
-House becomes so big that it's smarter to leave the game alone for 10 minutes and wait for a hint
-Events seems to trigger awkwardly
-Art could use work
-Lighting is glitchy
-Sound effects are glitchy
-The endgame (four key items + final level) is really cheap
-RNG death
-Generic story
-Sound design is amatuer, with sounds being RNG and music played haphazardly, in spite of their quality

I can't recommend this.  The early third of the game is pretty fun and interesting, but it quickly becomes a pain in the ass.   I would recommend getting it in a bundle or for 99 cents, although in that case you could just pick up a more competent indie horror title.  Or Nosferatu, which is badass.

That said, I'm looking forward to the next Pineview Drive.  A few tweaks to design and you'll have a unique, addictive little horror title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313773797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1510513902}
review:
Ein wirklich gelungenes Horrorgame f√ºr all diejenigen, die auf den klassischen Horror stehen und nicht auf Gemetzel und Splatter. Pineview Forest zeichnet sich mit klassischen Jumpscares und unheimlicher Musik aus. Das ganze Design vom Spiel ist wirklich gut gemacht. Das alte Haus sieht sehr sch√∂n aus aber ist von Anfang an doch etwas gruselig. Permanent sind unheimliche Ger√§usche da und man wei√ü nie was sich hinter der n√§chsten T√ºr verbrigt. Selbst wenn man die T√ºr schon mal ge√∂ffnet hat, hei√üt das nicht dass man dann dort nichts mehr zu bef√ºrchten hat. Mir hat es riesig Spa√ü gemacht und so machnes Mal doch kurz vor den Herzinfarkt gebracht. Die Demo ist kostenfrei und von daher sollte sie doch jeder mal anspielen um rauszufinden ob das Spiel einem zusagt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004814080', 'num_games_owned': 585, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1504024161}
review:
I just got to day 8 then decided to check the reviews and see how long the game actually is. When I saw it was 30 days, I decided it was time to give it up. 

For me, this game was a case of walking around until the character gives you a random hint (I wonder what's up with that painting in X room?), going to said place and then finding a key. This key then unlocks a random door. 

When you unlock the random door, one of 2 things will happen. You'll find a note, and the next day will begin, or you'll have to wander around looking for another key. 

The worst part is, it's not even scary!

Save your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106530933', 'num_games_owned': 1771, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1500067688}
review:
I won this game on steamgifts.com, actually it was the first game I win there. Now time for review.

Oh man, making a review for this game was quite tough... It was hard for me to think if I should recommend it or not but I think I finally made up my mind. 

So it all starts with you going to a house searching for your missing wife "Linda" thats when creepy stuff start happening...and thats pretty much all I can remember about the story in this game!
During 30 days you will try to look for some "evidence?" on what happened to her or some memories of her by searching for a finding notes scattered  all around different rooms in the house.

The Good:

+ The graphics (when you can actually see any shit) is decent.

+ The atmosphere.

+ While I usually never get scared in any horror game that game had got me once or twice since usually nothing happens but God! when something does happen its always in your face.

+ There is a new mechanisms in this game I never saw in any other game which is "Fear" If your character got scared enough you get a heart attack and die, however it doesn't always work as intended so yeah it needs some re-work.

+ Extra free update which adds a new mode to the game [strike] Slenderman [/strike] Scarecrow - The Eight Letters but I never been a fan of that type of horror games so i skipped playing it, still its a nice addition.

The Bad:

- Most boring gameplay ever! seriously for 29 days all you do is look for a key in every damn room or until your character gives you a clue about where to look then try that key on every god damn closed door until you open it then either find another key or find a note and the day ends...ofc somethings might creep on ya in these days but thats basically the core gameplay, things gets interesting only in the last day! I have been pushing myself to continue playing this because I won it if it was me who bought it I would probabaly have stopped at day 13 max.

- Framrate drop every now and then on highend pc.

- This one MIGHT contain spoilers so [b] SPOILER ALERT [/b] [spoiler] what really killed the game for me is realising that NOTHING can get me killed during the first 29 days so I just stopped caring after few days when I realised this, only in the last day I actually could get myself killed "intentionally" that is. And if in a horror game you don't get that feeling that you need to survive is it even scary anymore? And no I don't want that crap like in slenderman games in which if you got cought you lose all your progress I just want the right balance in between. [/spoiler]

- The ending just left me scratching my head even more about the story.

With that being said I saw great potential in this game really and I loved the way they created Linda's character with (you can see that in the credits) I loved how a small studio could put together something like this however I can not recommend it simply because the gameplay was kinda...boring and for the asked price you can get other horror games which have abit more interesing gameplay. However I recommend trying it at least if you got it in a bundle or a good sale.

I'm looking forward your upcoming game though. :)

Extra notes for the Devs:

#I liked that fear thing but it needs some re-work because sometimes I'm not even moving and my character would still get scared or sometimes I try to look at what is happening and my character would get scared even if I'm trying to move my camera slowly to look.
#Add more puzzles, and why don't you make every key has a sign or something and so do doors? Instead of trying the key on every single door.
#Need more interaction with other characters and need to know more about the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196172682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1496273775}
review:
The things I liked: The atmosphere, sound effects, and unlock and explore style of the game were really conducive to the overall creepy factor of the game. Finding keys, turning the corner and being spooked by ghosts or inanimate objects; all these things plus a great selection of sounds really paired well with the graphics of the house and yard to give you suspense each time you opened a new door. 

What I didn't like: Let's start with the worst of it, the ending. You spend hours playing through all these clues and rooms and it's all about finding your lost wife then you get to the end and it makes ZERO sense and ties in with the house and story in no way. The ending played out really fast and gave no explanations and I was let down big time. Another thing, the darkness. Almost no game play is done in any sort of daylight or house lighting. The dark really becomes monotonous  after you've already established a creepy, empty house and you have to work nearly the entire game in the dark with very very poor light sources (that you must renew, so good luck with that). Also, my particular version had a glitch about it that I was unable to pan and travel at the same time, which was really annoying. I had to move forward, stop, pan to whatever object I wanted, then move again accordingly. That could have been updated, not sure. 

In general, the gameplay isn't terrible. If you really like a suspenseful and creepy game that's mostly all exploration and collecting things, then you will really like this, despite its terrible ending and eye straining darkness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015132068', 'num_games_owned': 1103, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1480483179}
review: PINEVIEW DRIVE: This contains no spoilers, just gameplay instructions that I felt would of helped me when I played this game. Please do play Pineview drive. The sound design, atmosphere, and graphics are some of the most amazing i've seen in the horror game scene in a few years. The more you react to scares and do different things in the game it will adapt and attempt to scare you more. The health system is also based on this and how you react to scares.The scares and sounds will lead you to the next objective. This game does not hold your hand, you need to learn the twisting hallways of the house and where each room is, locked and unlocked. At some point it will become clear where to go or try as an objective, but it takes time to learn the house and plot to get there. You will arrive at a house that is almost completely locked up. You will need to find a keys over a total of 30 days to explore the house and property, on average unlocking a door or two a day. The day ends when you find a note that will expand on the story. The game takes patience. You will need to manage your light sources (match sticks and flashlight batteries). Flashlight starts to become unusable at 1 battery level. You will need to rely on lighting candles and jumping to and from lightsources to avoid losing health in the dark. Many who dislike the game run out of light sources and are lost in the darkness. You start each day with what you have left. There are additional spawns of batteries and matchsticks over the days throughout the already explored house. You can relight candle sticks. They will go out at the end of the night and they also have a chance of being blown out. The game has a day and night system, with the night coming sooner every passing day. If you take long enough and are unable to progress your character will remark about hearing a noise in a portion of the house or grounds to clue you where to go. The trick is to know where that is and how to get there. I found that it helped to find a place to hang out in the middle of the house conserving light sources and standing by a lit candle until your character gives you the clue to progress. I used a food storage room that opened from one side with a candle by the door and faced away from the window on nights I found I did not have enough light source to progress on my own and needed help. Even though this is in essence a key finding simulator, it takes a degree of skill to progress efficiently. After completing the game I had several critiques to the ending(the last night) as all the way to there I was blown away by the quality of the game. I felt the very tip of the end was lacking, but after understanding the plot and end, I accept it. On a side note in my opinion I wish the developer had put a limit on the matchsticks and candles to increase the difficulty and dismay camping. For instance candles would be spawned in a random condition (full stick, half stick, stub) that could hold a total of 3 times lighted by a matchstick and would degrade each time until they are unusable for the rest of the game. They would go out at the end of each night, and stay in the condition you left them in (3 use candle-> use-> lit-> chance of being blown out or night end->next day->2 use candle is there). I also would like if using a matchstick did not always work. The strike and spark, no fire (1/10 probability). It would make the decision to add a light or explore an area much more treacherous increasing the risk of taking a chance to find the keys. It also adds a level of punishment to new players who then learn throughout the nights that the candle resources are running out and would further push the player to learn how to conserve the resources and make smart decisions regarding paths to take through the house, learning new paths as shortcuts open up, and memorizing the layout of the house and candles. The game is full of easter eggs and is drawn from many horror sources. Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198081474791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1483302721}
review:
The main problem with Pineview Drive is it's core gameplay. Every day in the game, your task is to walk around in the house, hoping that something will happen which will give you a key. You use that key to open some doors. You find a note. Repeat.

The graphics and sound design is really nice, but OMG that pacing is terrible. It is incredibly boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010104993', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1520890597}
review:
The thing with this game is, it sucks, if you don't have proper sound output.
But when you play it with good headphones, this game is more scary than Outlast (yep i played it right before i started this game)
Outlast was a really good game, don't get me wrong, but after a while i wasn't scared.
Here it's totally different, the father I get into this game, the more and more scarier it gets for some reason. It's because you never know what's coming next and when. No, this game is not full of Jumpscares, they sure are some in it, but they are mostly well done in my opinion. It's more about the Atmosphere, Music and Ambience.

So All in All, the gameplay lacks a bit, you are always walking around, searching for the next key to open the next door, but if you want to get a game, which gets you on your limit with it's creepy atmosphere, GET IT! 

BUT Remember! ONLY PLAY THIS GAME WITH PROPER HEADPHONES, otherwise you won't get the full experience. THE SOUND, MUSIC AND AMBIENCE IS EVERYTHING IN THIS GAME!

author: {'steamid': '76561198143825031', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1482871262}
review:
Pineview Drive in its essence is one of the most atmospherically frightening games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. With its constantly tense background music and random spikes in sound effects and melody, it coninuously keeps the player on edge throughout the first half of the game. 
However, after the first 15 days the game becomes very repeatative and the lack of storyline or variety of sound and music as well as the jumpscares lose their effect. I must say, the second half of the game was hardly even startling despite the occasional jumpscare. The flashlight is also ridiculously dark with an extremely short battery life, making navigating the endless maze of the mansion in its extreme darkness almost impossible at times.

All in all, it's a good game but not nearly as good as it could be due to its lack of story, direction and variety.

Here's my full playthrough for anyone who's interested (Link to playlist): https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLYzlb9Rw0iBSMD7P3VizClX3FA3Il8myA

author: {'steamid': '76561198024812661', 'num_games_owned': 5784, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 1479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1479, 'last_played': 1482410316}
review:
Pineview Drive is a solid horror game, judging by the atmosphere it creates. Don't expect astonishing graphical quality, but it still gets the job done. If you are looking for a game that gives you the chills, then you should definitely give this a go.

Trying to avoid any spoilers here, I can only say that you advance through the game by following clues that eventually will unlock each room in the villa, one by one. Don't expect a mind-blowing story though. The clues required are not extremely intuitive at all times, but being persistent enough will eventually get you through (it took me a bit over 20 hours to finish it).

I also like the fact that the game is rather clean of issues (bugs).

author: {'steamid': '76561198082809570', 'num_games_owned': 2049, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1481485431}
review:
It's a bit too much of the same. 
Find a key, open a door, get a little spooked.
find a key, open a door, get a little spooked. 
It's not too bad all in all but it gets a bit monotonous. I also can't see anything with the ridiculous amount of darkness, my guy gets scared a lot by something I cannot see on screen. I find that pointless. I adjusted my brightness which only makes the dark grey-dark and I still can't see anything. If you find it in a bundle it might be worth your time. It's a bit reminiscent of Amnesia but not as much depth to it. All in all it's not a terrible game by any means I wish I could give it a Neutral review. So I'll go on the basis of the price tag, it's not worth a $20 price tag. 
A bundle, a sale, sure. This game could be a worthy candidate to have in your steam inventory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007382931', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1537688043}
review:
Probiert und aufgegeben. Spiel hat eine Grafik wie vor 10 Jahren. Aber eine schlechte Grafik vor 10 Jahren. Dabei fallen die FPS teilweise auf 20-30FPS. H√∂rt sich nicht schlimm an, rei√üt einen aber immer wieder aus dem Spiel.

Darauf hab ich einfach keine Lust nach solch einer Perle wie Layers of Fear.
Schade, hatte mich auf das Spiel gefreut, aber das geht einfach nicht. Bsp. gleich am Anfang steht man neben einem Auto das aussieht als ob es keine Texturen im Inneren hat. Man h√§tte doch einfach mal ein schlichtes Cockpit darstellen k√∂nnen und nicht nur Texturmatsche. Kein Plan wer sich gedacht hat so etwas macht sich gut in einem Spiel.

Immerhin passt sich der Rest an. Ruckeln und Grafik wie aus der guten alten Zeit. Hach, "wie sch√∂n". Da lieber Minecraft in Ruckelfrei mit einem Grafikstil der dazu passt. Aber Gruselspiel mit b√§h Optik und ruckeln geht einfach bei mir heute nicht mehr.

BTW: Am Rechner liegt es nicht. GTA5 und Battlefield 1 z.B. laufen wunderbar fl√ºssig bei mir.

Davor hat alles funktioniert und jetzt geht gar nix mehr bei mir und die Voraussetzungen haben sich nicht ge√§ndert.. W√ºrde gerne weiter spielen... was ist da los ??? LG _DE_Schahida_

author: {'steamid': '76561197970602587', 'num_games_owned': 6364, 'num_reviews': 3660, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1479181487}
review:
https://youtu.be/L4TntY7iGv8

An exploration based game with horror themes that is critically weakened by insurmountable darkness that makes the game virtually unplayable without major gamma adjustments.

Even after a lethal dose of gamma radiation, the core gameplay loop involves finding a key then checking every locked door to find anouther key to then repeat the process.  Keys are unlabeled and indistinguishable leading to infuriating mystery meat level design.

Also there are occasional spooky sounds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031235256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1677444405}
review: The game has the best atmosphere of any horror game I have ever played and it has plenty of good scares to keep you entertained. However, the game is a bit slow and can be frustrating when your navigating the house looking for the keys. Also the game is really dark and it makes it hard to see with out a flashlight... I really hope they change this in the the squeal. Overall it's a great game and well worth a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987894383', 'num_games_owned': 1010, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1545349638}
review: Ein very slow walking simulator, dessen kompliziertestes Puzzle nach 51 Spielminuten das Finden der korrekten T√ºr f√ºr einen der √ºberall einfach so rumliegenden Schl√ºssel. Also, man muss sich das etwa so vorstellen. Man steht vor einem verschlossenen Tor. Man schleicht darauf zu, bis das Schlo√ü rot umrandet wird, damit man auch ganz genau wei√ü, was man tun muss. Man dr√ºckt die Aktionstaste, wobei Aktion irgendwie die falsche Vokabel f√ºr dieses Spiel ist, und bekommt gesagt, dass man das Schloss √∂ffnen muss, um sich Zutritt zu dem Gel√§nde zu verschaffen. Ach so, ja, ok. Wie man das am besten tut, bekommt man auch gesagt, kann es sich aber eigentlich denken, denn man kann weder springen noch klettern noch sonst irgendwas, nur schleichen. Jedenfalls muss man den Schl√ºssel f√ºr das Schloss finden. Aaaaaahhh, ja, ok, dann such ich den mal. Oh, da liegt er ja, auf dem Boden, 3 Schritte neben mir auf dem Boden. Fast nur zwei Minuten sp√§ter ist man die 3m vor und zur√ºck gegangen und das Tor √∂ffnet sich. Von alleine. Man schleicht auf das Anwesen zu. Dann bekommt man ganz langsam die n√§chste Aufgabe eingeh√§mmert: am besten verschaffe man sich erstmal Zutritt zu dem Geb√§ude. W√§re ich jetzt nicht drauf gekommen, mach ich dann mal. Irgendwann dann an der einzigen T√ºr angekommen leuchtet auch schon die Klinke. Und? Ratet? Richtig. Ist verschlossen. Was muss man machen? Na? Genau. Den Schl√ºssel suchen. Wobei die Vokabel suchen auch wieder nicht ganz richtig ist, denn der Schl√ºssel liegt gleich daneben auf dem Fensterbrett. Jetzt wird es komplizierter. 3 T√ºren. Und? Jo. Schl√ºssel suchen. Dann der Hammer! Eine der drei T√ºren ist offen. Uuuuuhhhh. Und was ist dahinter? Ein Gang. Mit ganz vielen T√ºren. Und? Yep. Verschlossen. Aber gleich 3 Schritte weiter liegt.... Spannung bis zum Schluss... Na? Ein Schl√ºssel. Jetzt wird es aber interessant, denn man hat ja nicht die geringste Ahnung, zu welcher der T√ºren der passen k√∂nnte. Und bis man die T√ºren alle angeschlichen hat... so, ich muss ins Bett, Nacht Leude.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972394559', 'num_games_owned': 1974, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1475795094}
review:
There are some decent scares in this game but 90% of the time you will get lost and frustrated trying to find keys or waiting for the next scripted event to happen so you can progress.

The game also has performance issues on my powerful PC. 

Buy it on low sale if you feel you want to give it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269659324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1478725592}
review:
Spiel hat mich positiv √ºberrascht. Nach dem ich in den ersten Tagen noch dachte, ist ja alles nicht so schlimm, hatte ich gegen Ende Angst vor meinem eigenen Schatten. Das Spiel hat mich immer wieder √ºberrascht und hat auch einige Wendungen in der Geschichte. Ich musste mich regelrecht √ºberwinden, weiter zu spielen vor lauter Angst. 

Man muss viel und oft suchen, in den ersten Tagen findet man das vielleicht langweilig aber je weiter man kommt desto schlimmer wird das suchen und jeden Tag erfahren wir mehr √ºbre Linda. 

Doch was passiert ist muss jeder selbstheraus finden.

Der Clown und die Vogelscheuche verhalten sich immer mal wieder anders. Unberechenbar halt.

Mir hat es gefallen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 8154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1521393278}
review:
One of the better horror games I have played in a long while. Graphics are pleasing, sound is superb, atmosphere is amazing.

Only the gameplay itself it quite tedious, as you are running around in the mansion for so many days, getting key after key and then running down the entire building again to see which door you'll be able to open afterwards.

But even with that repetition, the atmosphere absolutely delivers a great mixture of jumpscares as well as a steadily more and more creepy atmosphere.

I do defenitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007752744', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1613914803}
review:
I can understand why so many people dont rate this game. It does has it flaws and can be frustrating looking for keys in the dark or wondering what you are supposed to be doing at times. You can easily miss some of the scares especially if you are looking the wrong way... And the story is vague, especially the ending.

However I think this game is way underated in the horror genre. This game scared me more than Slender, Outlast, Amnesia or any of the others. It has amazing way of filling you with dread, which progressivley gets worse as the days go by and can make you incredibly paranoid. The atmosphere it creates especially with its audio effects has to be the scariest ive experienced in a game -and i have played heaps of horror titles. You get used to some of the jumpscares, and some are really cliched. But some are so unexpectedly good your blood will run cold. This game scares more on subtle levels than in your face jumpscares though - I hate scarecrows and clowns more than ever now..

... I cant even finish scarecrow the 8 pages coz its just too scary - way freakier than slender...

8/10
Pros
 - creepy as hell            
 - panic inducing
 - atmosphere and audio are great

cons
 - can be repetitive especially if you get lost
 - key simulator
 - not enough batteries
 - lags at times

author: {'steamid': '76561198042052301', 'num_games_owned': 3072, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1470775384}

author: {'steamid': '76561198006957460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1636322642}
review:
I can see why many people may not like this game. I find it questionable, but Steam doesn't offer a middle line for reviews (and the fact that the game got me good the first time I tried it is the only reason I'm rating it positive).

My only complaints so far is the whole key-fetching system (can get annoying), the hint system forces you to wait if you don't know what to do, unless you bump straight into what you need to do, I was unable to fetch the story by the end of the game. The game's performance (mostly blamable on me because of my PC, but others with a GTX970 also complained of performance issues) is rather sporadic, especially when all the shadows are rendering (puts me to ~10FPS), so I have to wait until it turns dark to reach ~40FPS.

The game has its potential, but the execution part fell short IMO. This is also one of those games you may like, you may not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020505922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1586467782}
review: This is unplayable due to the darkness of the game. While a horror game ought to be dark, it's important to SEE SOMETHING! 0,3 hours is nothing but keep in mind that 0,05 hours were spent seeing something and the rest being completely blinded. If I want to stare at a dark screen, I would turn my computer off.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968729302', 'num_games_owned': 1937, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1469913744}
review:
Coming from someone who loves horror games (Outlast, Amnesia series, Layers of Fear, Soma, Penumbra, etc), I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.  Warning:  This is not a fast paced game!  If you get bored with slow paced games, don't look here.  However, if you love a slow building creepy as hell atmosphere that builds and builds as the game moves along, this is the game to play.  A good blend of slow, psychological horror from the atmosphere and terrifying jump scares.  This game got my adrenaline pumping many times.  The only real complaint I have is with the last day.  I won't post any spoilers, but I was disappointed with the ending.  It does make me curious to see where they go with this franchise, however.

8/10, would play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983485859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1470494336}
review:
I wonder if the extreme darkness of the game is a feature or a bug (it's a strong possibility, since there are other graphic bugs, at least in the Linux version). Even with the room lamps on, you can't see the other side of the room. Maxing bright helps a bit, playing in a dark room maybe, but I couldn't get enough contrast to see things even in supposedly well illuminated rooms. The game highlights objects when revisiting a room, but it's not enough. In the end, after barely an hour, I had sore eyes.

Other issues with the title have been mentioned in the other reviews.

It's sad dropping such a short negative review from this little playtime, but it actually hurts playing the game.

Note: since Steam now asks if I got the game for free, I should probably mention that I got the game in a SteamGifts giveaway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099274185', 'num_games_owned': 1833, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1469824168}
review: I think this game is good and does a job well of scaring you, and some parts of the game will scare you when you are not really ready for it. The graphics are really nice and the design is awesome. Some parts may have been a bit of a challenge, but this is mostly related to the story, which was a little less explained that some might have hoped. Also, this could be a good thing as this game gives much more questions than answers. Also this is good that you get to think some on your own on what really happened as not much is served beforehand. Clues and guidance were a bit lacking and some thing maybe could have been made less problematic, like finding what doors a certain key should fit into. Also, in a sense, this was a good thing, as you are constantly on the edge and not knowing really what will happen next or where you should go. Also performance could have been better i suppose. The ending i think was fitting and surely gives a feeling there would be a follow-up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026882081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1549327000}
review:
Should have been named Key finder simulator. In key finder simulator the player is task with finding little silver keys that are placed in odd locations and then taking those little silver keys and finding the doors that corresponds with the right key, Unlike games like resident evil these keys do not have markings on them that tell you which door to use them on and instead relys on the simple approach of going around the mansion  and clicking every single door handle until you find the one that will unlock.

 Also sometimes keys appear when events happen so if you see something or hear something near you in the game, look toward the ground their might be a key.

The storyline to the game is given to you in what I can only call sentences basically after opening said amount of doors each day using the keys you will find a page in a room that will end the day and give you a little bit of the story and like I said before the amount of story you get from these pages is around a sentence, a good example of what you might get would look something like this Martha choked on a sandwitch today unfortunaelly we were unable to save her. 

Another problem the game has is that it does not tell the player what keys to push to interact with the game you basically have to figure it out for yourself. 

Also if I havent mentioned it already the keys spawn in some odd locations the first key spawns spoiler alert= below a sign took me around fifteen to twenty mintues to find that key and figure out how to interact with the gate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022455711', 'num_games_owned': 1662, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1468711997}
review:
Also zuerst einmal muss ich sagen das ich Pineview Drive ohne gro√üe Erwartungen gestartet habe, da die wenigstens Horror Spiele heutzutage wirklich gruselig sind. Und was soll ich sagen, ich wurde sehr sehr positiv √ºberrascht! Nat√ºrlich ist es so das an den ersten paar Tagen nicht wirklich was passiert, das Spiel versucht halt nicht einem Horror mit dem Dampfhammer einzutrichtern, aber es baut sich dennoch schon ein wohliges Gef√ºhl von Bedr√ºckung aus, wenn man durch die ehrw√ºrdigen Hallen dieses Riesenhauses spaziert. 

Zuerst nat√ºrlich noch mit viel Tageslicht und gut ausgeleuchteten R√§umen ohne das man vom Haus und seinen Bewohnern gro√üartig bel√§stigt wird, wobei sich auch hier am Anfang schon eine gro√üe St√§rke des Spiels bemerkbar macht, der Sound. Die Ger√§uschkulisse fand ich mit eine der besten die ich bis jetzt in Horrorspielen erlebt habe und passt immer zu der stets bedrohlich werdenden Atmosph√§re im Haus, ein Wispern dort, ein tosender Sturm oder auch Schritte in dem Zimmer √ºber einem. Diese Dinge werden noch nat√ºrlich noch mehr und vielf√§ltiger ebenso wie das Haus seine gesamte Wirkung erst nach und nach entfaltet.

Das ‚ÄûZiel‚Äú des Spiels und des Protagonisten, jeden Tag aufs neue wieder Schl√ºssel zu suchen um sein Tagebuch zu vervollst√§ndigen und herauszufinden was mit seiner Frau Linda vor 20 Jahren hier geschehen ist, mag anfangs eint√∂niger klingen als es ist. Nat√ºrlich gibt es Tage wo man sich denkt ‚ÄûAlter, wo soll ich denn hin ich war doch schon √ºberall‚Äú aber oft f√ºhren einen die ‚ÄûErscheinungen‚Äú selbst in die richtige Richtung. Wenn man aber partout nicht weiter kommt gibt einem der Protagonist selbst einen fast schon Hellseherischen Tipp √† la ‚ÄûIch sollte wohl mal im Kinderzimmer im zweiten Stock nachsehen ich glaube dort bewegt sich was‚Äú was bei den dutzenden R√§umen und im Halbdunkel aber oft auch kein Fehler ist. Die Schl√ºssel selber sind alle durchwegs fair versteckt, wenn man sich die Zeit nimmt in Ruhe und Gr√ºndlichkeit die R√§ume zu durchsuchen, wer wei√ü auf was man dabei noch so alles st√∂√üt. ;) 

Die Grafik mag f√ºr manche vielleicht etwas Altbacken wirken, was sie vielleicht manchmal auch sein mag, aber ich fand sie pers√∂nlich jetzt nie h√§sslich oder sonst was. Wenn man sich im Haus genau umschaut erkennt man auch das von Seiten der Entwickler wirklich aufs Detail geschaut wurde, Betten die benutzt aussehen, Essen das am Tisch auf jemanden wartet und so weiter. Leute die nat√ºrlich einfach wie auf Speed durchrennen, auf nichts achten und alle kleinen Feinheiten bewusst ignorieren, die werden mit dem Spiel sicher keine Freude haben.

Nat√ºrlich gibt es auch ein paar kleine Mankos, keine Frage. Zum einen finde ich es Schade, dass man w√§hrend des Spiels nicht mehr √ºber das Haus und seine Bewohner erf√§hrt durch B√ºcher, Zettel oder √§hnliches, bin da pers√∂nlich echt ein gro√üer Freund von, dies d√ºrfte aber wohl f√ºr einen 2ten Teil aufgespart worden sein. Ebenfalls muss man erw√§hnen das sich gewisse Effekte (Visuell wie Audiotechnisch) mit der Zeit nat√ºrlich abnutzen und mit der Zeit etwas an Schauderhaftigkeit verlieren. 
Was ich f√ºr mich pers√∂nlich aber als gr√∂√üten Minuspunkt empfand, mag aber evtl. auch von Spieler und Spielweise abh√§ngen, war eben die Tatsache das man an manchen Tagen wirklich herumirrt und nur darauf wartet das der Protagonist einem sagt in welchen Zimmer sich was bewegt hat um weiter zu kommen, allerdings sind diese Tage zum Gl√ºck eher selten.

So zum Abschluss bleibt nur zu sagen nat√ºrlich dieses Spiel ist kein z. B. Outlast, aber will und muss es auch gar nicht! Horror wird hier eben nicht nur durch Splatter und Gore Effekte entwickelt und aufgebaut, sondern durch die Kombination aus Dunkelheit, Beklemmung, Sound und eigener Vorstellungskraft. Also kein Spiel f√ºr Leute bei denen das Blut nur so spritzen muss. :D aber eines f√ºr Leute die einen guten Horror einem blutigen vorziehen!

Auch ein richtig fettes DANKE an die Entwickler, daf√ºr das ich es mir jetzt zweimal √ºberlege eine T√ºr im Dunkeln zu √∂ffnen, k√∂nnte ja eine bestimmte Dame dahinter auftauchen ;) Und nochmals Hut ab habe mich lange bei einem Spiel nicht sehr so gef√ºrchtet!
PS: Clown und Vogelscheuchen sind Freunde ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198078815949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1468556076}
review:
When it comes to horror games, Pineview Drive is an interesting breed of game.

The Initial Feeling

- When you boot up the game and get into it, you're treated with an annoying start.  You're outside this large gate with a mansion just teasing you over the edge.  It takes a moment for you to find the key you need to open up the gate and dive into things.  An awkward start, though don't let that fool you into thinking you wasted your money.

Cons

- It 'can' be hard to see the jump scares, this is true.  There are a lot of things happening, sometimes you don't even see it.  A ghost is behind you and touches you (I think that's what happened) or something was on the other side of the door and you turned away missing it.  For a horror game, that can get annoying.  Though, a lot of it is repetive stuff you'll most likely see...  eventually.

- The 'Fear' mechanic of the game (The bar in the top left) is, admittedly, the downfall of this game.  Initially, I thought, 'Wow, this is new!'.  For one, I typically avoid horror games I'm unable to fight back.  They're not immersive enough for me, though I do play them from time to time due to a horrible lack of 'Good' horror titles.  Anyways, the 'Fear' mechanic in this seems to be far to random to be reliable.  Essentially (The game doesn't tell you this), when a jump scare happens, such as a phone ringing, a ghost appearing, something flying in your face, the game will pick up your actions via the mouse and keyboard.  This determines whether or not that meter drops down.  If it goes away, you die, presumably.  After much testing this mechanic, it seemed like it was far to random for you to become conditioned to not jump at various things, thus being able to progress.  Some things just drain your meter no matter what.  While being an interesting feature, it would be much more interesting if it had some consistency to it.

- It can be frustrating to try and figure out where to go.   This game pretty much requires you to wear headphones with the volume as high as your ears can stand.  I found myself wandering around most nights going 'Where do I go?'.  Eventually, the main character would give a hint then I could finally go and progress because I couldn't hear whatever I was supposed to be hearing.

- It takes...  way to long to get to the most frightening parts.  Initially it's just your cliche paranormal things before it advances into a hellish jump scare mayhem.  While the later part of that is good for the game, the first 20 nights feel more like the ghosts aren't even trying.

Pros

- It is a beautiful game, the developer should be proud of their work.  The rain looks nice, the mansion looks nice, and the weather effects do add quite a bit to the game.

- The atmosphere is spot on, with the little noises here and there to make you always wonder 'Should I be worried about?'.  You feel like you're immersed with the noises in a haunted mansion.

- Upon reaching the later nights the game becomes rather frightening.  It just takes time to get to those points.  I won't say any spoilers of what those scares are but I found them to be well done, even if some are. admittedly, hard to witness.

Final Verdict

I'd set this game as a 6/10 final review.  It's good for a one time full playthrough, if you don't become to annoyed with the 'Fear' meter.  If you can manage to get that to cooperate, the game is fairly well made.  If the 'Fear' meter worked better this could easily be an 8, if not a 9, out of ten.  Give it a try.  I'd recomeend snagging it on a Special Deal day.  Twenty bucks isn't to bad but there is no replay value and the buggy Fear can cause more frustration than enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2121, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1468525786}
review:
Game just oozes with potential but questionable design decisions make this a game of attrition where players time and patience is put to the test. 

Problems i see broken down to detail:

1) Running up and down between floors trying keys - and occasionalyl going to gates/back door to try your luck. That back door itself is bad mistake as the player cannot know if the latest key is for it or not. So around you go when keys you have doesnt go into any door. 
2) Game hints at getting the right key for the current door. But instead it counts how many keys you have. And thats it. You have to try doors again and again and maybe this time a key works. 
3) Another reviewer pointed out that there are ghosts clamoring for attention - but you cant see them because of darkness. This really is so. Darkness is an important element yes but you still cannot really see anything worth mentioning. So you ignore stuff until its right in front of you. 
4) Huge mansion. 2 floors and a yard and no way to know where you are needed next. I just spent some 3 hours running around and completing days until i just couldnt go on anymore. I care not for the notes that advance the day.  What is the point? I can see the potential - But also the flaws are so hardcoded in front of you and other reviewers state the same. I prefer tight spaces like in Anna anyday to running around in empty areas. 
5) Found a new key? Chances are you wont find the correct door anytime soon or anywhere near you. Back and forth you go. 

Dont believe me? Just pick any walktrough video on youtube or in the guides for this game. Skip around randomly - See how the player is constantly trying out doors. Why did they overdo this? I just cant get it around my head why devs decided to test the players patience like this. Sure some will like it. Some have completed the game but for me this is too sleepy material. And i sure am not scared. I dislike the mechanics too much for that.
