author: {'steamid': '76561198045513359', 'num_games_owned': 2569, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1435076071}
review:
The Good 
Atmosphere is quite well and I like the voice acting (which is the best thing in this game imho).

The Bad
Only scary if you are easily scared by just a bit a strange voice and some cheap scares. The pace of the game is crippled crawl, there's no puzzle whatsoever, many design choice seems pointless. But the worst of it all is the pitchblack darkness in this game. Instead of adding to the scare, it only give me more frustration. If you can't see the jump scare, then what's the point !?!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042018268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1429199127}
review:
I'm not such a fan of Horror Adventure games, but this one I really enjoyed.
Same with Gone Home, I went through this one without a clue what the game was about.
For Gone Home however, it was quite a different story. This game actually had some scary parts.

This game has a really amazing atmosphere. At day it feels really safe, but at night.. Who knows what will happen.
I eventually fled from the game cause I chickened out.. I remember having 3 keys which none of them fit in any lock.
I went outside to check if the gate fit any of the keys, when my flashlight suddenly went out..
I was left alone in the dark with nothing but a far away lighthouse to keep me from turning insane.
Suddenly I heard footsteps and they weren't mine. The first thing I did was close the game.

This being such more of a scary experience to me than any game that want to scare the player so consistantly is really interesting. The fact that you don't know when you should be scared and when not to is a really good part of this game.


[b]+ Good Elements[/b]
Good Atmosphere
Great Sound
Pleasant Control

[b]- Fixable Elements[/b]
(as far as I have read) Too Many Days, Too Many Keys..
Odd Intro
Finite batteries?


I certainly do recommend this game dispite my issues with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995149184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1429134447}
review:
Absolute crap.  Once again, it's wander around in the dark and look for matches, keys, and a flashlight that I don't think exists.  You can't jump, the restrictions the game puts on you are rediculous, and it's formulaic and cliche.

Stop making games like this.  Dark does not equal scary. Slow moving doesn't equal scary, odd noises that are recognizable but out of place does not equal scary, and billion locked doors aren't scary.

Just stop with this crap and make a game that entertains first, and scares second.

review:
No es el Outlast o Amnesia pero lo recomiendo, a√∫n no lo he acabado pero de momento yo ya lo considero buena compra. Ideal para amantes de casas misteriosas en plan POE, si buscas zombies o man√≠acos sanguinarios abstente.

PROS
Fant√°stica atm√≥sfera, iluminaci√≥n y sonidos hacen de la casa un lugar inquietante seg√∫n avanzas en el juego.
Casa muy detallada, es agradable recorrerla.
Sustos variados, desde el t√≠pico sobresalto facil√≥n al aumento del nerviosismo poco a poco mediante sonidos, susurros, pasos...
Tiene algunas escenas memorables, la llamada nocturna a la puerta es de lo mejor.
El sistema de cap√≠tulos divididos en d√≠as con la ca√≠da de la noche es original y c√≥modo.
Pistas, velas y pilas hacen entretenido recorrer la casa.

CONS:
La optimizaci√≥n, me va bien, pero justito y mi ordenador mueve agilmente el Farcry 3 a tope, un poco mas trabajado este apartado hubiera estado bien.
Es recomendable prestar atenci√≥n y memorizar qu√© puertas quedan por abrir para no pegarse la paliza recorriendo toda la casa una y otra vez. Si vas a lo loco te aburrir√°s.

CONSEJO:
No hay armas, tampoco hay nada corporeo que te persiga, hay cerillas y pilas suficiente para explorar pero no te molestes en encender todo, cada nuevo d√≠a todo se apaga, recomiendo encender velas en sitios nuevos para ahorrar bater√≠as.
Las llaves no est√°n muy escondidas, pero no te dejes rinc√≥n, ba√±era o estanter√≠a sin mirar o te liar√°s a dar vueltas y tendr√°s que volver.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022189669', 'num_games_owned': 1857, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1428365722}
review:
6/10

Pineview Drive is a game with a lot of potential. Sadly, that potential was not fully realised. Perhaps that potential will come true in later updates, but at this stage I cannot give it a good review. It aims for a haunted house simulator, but comes off as more of a key-and-locked-door simulator. It has some really decent aspects to the game such as the immersion, but the negatives are so much more impinging that the positives get lost.

POSITIVES:

+ An excellent voice actor.
+ Great immersion.
+ Some scares later into the game that actually made me jump.
+ A great transition in the increase in intensity of scares as the game progresses.
+ Taking too long to find the point of progression will give you a dialogue clue.

NEGATIVES:

- Execution of the main game idea. Yes, it is obviously a haunted house, and some of the scares are great. But it ultimately boils down to wake up from the night, wait until the game hits the darkest possible point of the night cycle, listen to an audio cue, head to the room with the audio trigger (if you can even work out what it was), find a key, check every single locked door hoping that the key corresponds to that lock, end that night.

- Very limited plot. There is a very brief narrative that 'fleshes out' the story at the end of each night. Also, the point is never raised as to why you find keys to certain rooms locked away in other rooms, just sitting on a table or the floor, effectively creating a 'puzzle'. Surely this would be a massive imposition to the home owner.

- RIDICULOUS darkness. Don't let the screenshots fool you, this game is DARK. It has your classic horror elements of a flashlight and candles for you to light, where you find sparse matches and batteries to help light your way. However, the lighting physics is fairly unrealistic - lights will strongly illuminate the area directly surrounding them, but will shroud the remainder of the room / corridor in COMPLETE darkness. When I have both a candelabra lit and a light switch turned on in a short hallway, I shouldn't have to whip out my flashlight just to see the door handle in front of me. There were actually times I was shocked to see a door that I had passed several times, but not noticed due to terrible lighting. Also, this was on MAX BRIGHTNESS SETTING. Considering that the entirety of the game is searching for small changes in room layouts and small keys that are often in completely illogical places, this is a terrible mechanic.

- Counter-intuitive plot devices. Almost the entirety of the game revolves around audio triggers, and heading to the location where you thought the trigger came from. However, the audio is often completely unrelated to the 'trigger'. ** VERY MILD SPOILER** For example, I hear what sounds like glass shattering, after having just discovered a room with a large glass cabinet. Nope. I proceed to check the four or five locations with croquery, thinking a piece may have fallen and shattered. Nope. It turns out to be a fallen sword, which I hadn't even visually seen up until that point, due to its location and the poor lighting. **END VERY MILD SPOILER **

All in all, Pineview Drive is a great game to kill time with, and play a few hours on for the experience, but expect to get extremely bored and frustrated backtracking to doors that have previously been locked, and finding small objects in complete darkness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041717774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1428356212}
review:
This game really did have potential.

It has a nice and creepy atmosphere with a nice mechanic involving scaring you when the game feels you 'need' it based on twitchy movement and looking around often.

However, any semblance of fun this game might have had is ruined by the actual gameplay. You wander around the exact same house repeatedly. At first you look for keys to open more of the house. Soon you're just searching for whatever usable thing has appeared in this particular day at the house so that you can progress. That's it. This single handedly makes the game awful. You literally just comb the same rooms repeatedly whilst the game occasionally throws a loud noise your way.

Terrible, and I got it in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040354836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 267, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1408050690}
review:
At first this indie horror game is surprisingly pleasant and scary indeed, as you find yourself in the secluded house surrounded by the darkness filled with unsettling rustlings and weird murmurs. But as soon as you realise how the game works, it all immediately becomes boring and predictable. You walk in circles through the same dark rooms, meeting from time to time the same cliched jump scares. This is the exact description of the gameplay.
Oh, and the ending here is nonexistent. But there is a doll. A doll, really?

author: {'steamid': '76561198076924830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1426999126}
review:
Do you like playing games on finding out which key goes to which door, constant back and forth? Do you like running around waiting for shit to happen or trigger so you can continue with the damn story? Or do you like games that are not scary AT ALL and resorts to cheap jump scares? THEN THIS GAME IS FOR YOU! 

[b][u]BUT FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, DO NOT SPEND $19.99 FOR THIS GAME![/b][/u] It is only worth while if it's free, otherwise you are wasting your time! I'm sure this developer really did try at making this game entertaining, but it falls soooo short it hurts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042261571', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1426451342}
review:
It's a haunted house simulator. What do you REALLY want? Are you looking for some grand masterpiece? This isn't it. It's just something to egg yourself on with because you refuse to be beaten by a virtual spooky house.

While realizing the statues and busts are most certainly looking at you and nosily watching your every movement, but reset their positions the moment you set your eyes on them, I finally spazzed out and took my frustration out on a cherub. "(EXPLECTIVE)ing BABY ANGELS!"

That adorable little kitty statue you might think is the only precious thing in this game? No they'll take that away from you. Yes that's a ghost girl doing a little Sheldon Cooper outside your door. Knock knock knock, MAIN CHARACTER. Knock knock knock, MAIN CHARACTER. See you in hell, Sheldon!

Birds that rustle around and make unsettling noises when you explore outside? Thanks. I already have a fear from Hitchcock but this just brings it all rushing back. Creepy toys around the house, some of which with an impact upon the plot? We got that. A scarecrow in the uncanny valley territory? Mmhm, yeah we got that. Blood! Tasteful, but gracious when needed! Yeah, we've got it!

Pretty much any haunted house trope you can think of was put into a blender, had a curse to chill it with, and then served as some Boo! Smoothie.

Your scare factor may vary. While this game boasts being able to find out and track (more like punishes through your health bar) what frightens you, I've noticed my character tends to mostly gasp at disembodied noises. This makes me paranoid and angry. Angry that I can't find a ghost to smack with my flashlight! If you're more of a jerky player and have the need to constantly move to find what made noises or move when you are faced with a jump scare, you'll likely get a new batch of scares.

A minor gripe? If you are suddenly lost and have no idea where to go, you'll run out of batteries and matches quickly. Ghosts love to play poof with your candles and later on in the days, you'll find matches very precious. When the fire goes out, it's all that more irritating. Your flashlight will suddenly pick up a little charge from not being used, so don't worry too much. You're not lost in the dark for long! It's just slightly irritating. If you keep wandering, your character will eventually give you a hint, but that takes a great deal of time. However, some of the very fun "scares" can happen this way. Just uh, stay away from the windows. Or don't. So far I've been pressing my face against the busts and yelling BRING IT ON but things BEHIND me have been lowering my health, so don't do that.

Second minor gripe? I had heard through the grapevine that the ending was very confusing, so I spoiled myself before buying. I'm not saying that everyone should do this, but if you're really on the fence after reading these and knowing an ending won't influence you either way, you may want to do that. It really is confusing and going in while knowing what was going to happen helped me understand just why things didn't really add up from the start. This may not work for all gamers, though it was helpful for me.

You'll be learning the storyline through short notes found at the end of each day. Even then, you may never get closure of what happened to your character.To be perfectly honest after playing this and Passing Pineview Forest, I'm finding a storyline that I've enjoyed and I'd like to see more of. I need to know more about Pineview. How many victims are there? I'm not even completely done and I'm very interested in seeing more.

Still, this isn't for everyone. This is a haunted house simulator, but it's much more of a puzzle/maze type game than say, an Amnesia clone or a Slender clone. Although there...is a mode for a Slender level... But I haven't unlocked that yet and I don't think I have the guts to do so. This game can get tedious for some people. For others you're just going to end up getting more frustrated because you don't want this house to outwit you. Stupid house. Stupid lights.

GIVE ME SOME MATCHES! And boop that clown!

...Where did the clown go?

author: {'steamid': '76561198019340351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1425673534}

author: {'steamid': '76561198077527825', 'num_games_owned': 1981, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 2399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1732, 'last_played': 1429039682}
review:
That farkin CAT!

10/10 would poopoo my pantsu again

EDIT: Upon finishing...

It really is a great game, right up until that ending...that was sh!t, that ending. Up until then, the devs had used the music cues and ambient sounds faultlessly, ramping things up every now and then to the point where you just KNOW there's gonna be a jump scare around the next corner or on the other side of the door you're about to open, but there isn't. Wonderfully misleading. And when the few jump scares DO happen, they genuinely gave me a jump.

Back to the ambient noises for a moment though, they really are brilliantly done, all the rustling, the creaks, the footsteps, the whispered 'psst', even the rain...all of it fantastic and all of it adds to the unnerving feeling the game gives you...

If you can forgive the ending it's definitely worth a pickup, even at full price

author: {'steamid': '76561198017392185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1423916350}
review:
Een interessant concept, maar waardeloze uitvoering.

Een horrorspel waar je energie verliest als je angst toont. Dat klinkt interessant, maar het komt er in de praktijk op neer dat je een deel van je levensbalk verliest als je plotselinge bewegingen maakt met je muis (ongeacht de oorzaak). Het verhaal gaat dat je vriendin 20 jaar geleden is verdwenen in het grote landhuis aan het einde van Pineview Drive en dat sindsdien niemand het daar langer dan 30 dagen heeft uitgehouden. Jij besluit het lot te tarten en het wel langer dan 30 dagen uit te houden in de hoop meer te weten te komen over de verdwijning van je vriendin. Na een korte tocht door de tuinen van het huis, stap je naar binnen en begint het echte spel. Het huis ziet er mooi uit en er is duidelijk zorg besteed aan het ontwerp. En dan wordt het buiten avond en wordt het donker in het huis, pikdonker. Lampen aandoen heeft wel enig effect, maar in tegenstelling tot de werkelijkheid schijnt licht in dit spel niet verder dan een meter of twee. Blijkbaar gelden de normale natuurwetten niet en worden fotonen door een onzichtbare muur tegengehouden. Zelfs met alle lichten aan, blijft een donkere kamer dus grotendeels donker en ziet er uit als een schilderij van Rembrandt met een 'claire obscure' effect. Je vindt gelukkig een zaklamp, maar deze zuigt batterijen nog sneller leeg dan de zaklamp die ik ooit in een vlaag van verstandsverbijstering bij een Chinese online winkel bestelde. Net als bij de overige lampen, schijnt het zwakke licht van de zaklamp niet ver en als de batterijen eenmaal op zijn, moet je op de tast je weg zien te vinden. Je kunt ook lucifers gebruiken om kaarsen aan te steken, maar ook die geven weinig licht. En als je zaklamp leeg is, heb je een probleem, want zelfs met de lichten aan, zijn deuren die zich in een donkere hoek van de kamer bevinden (en dat zijn de meeste) moeilijk te vinden. En je kunt ze alleen openen door precies op de deurklink te klikken (die je niet kunt zien in het donker). In mijn eerste (en laatste) poging dit spel te spelen heb ik er ruim een kwartier over gedaan om een kamer uit te komen. Je enige doel in dit spel is sleutels vinden en deuren openen. Heb je na lang zoeken een sleutel gevonden, dan begint de nog langere zoektocht naar de dichte deur waar de sleutel op past. Verwacht niet dat er op de sleutel enige indicatie staat van de deur waar hij op past, dus je zult (opnieuw) het hele huis moeten doorlopen. En na verloop van tijd (zo las ik in andere reviews) zijn deuren die je eerder hebt geopend opeens weer op slot en moet je opnieuw de sleutel zoeken. Als je genoeg deuren hebt geopend, wordt het weer dag en na een paar minuten wordt het weer avond en mag je weer door het donker strompelen. Af en toe wordt je bezocht door een geestachtige verschijning, althans, zo las ik in een andere review, maar zo lang heb ik het niet uitgehouden. Nadat ik de eerste avond had overleefd, begon de speurtocht naar sleutels opnieuw. En al zien de kamers van het huis er mooi uit, er is niets te doen behalve lampen aandoen en de sleutel zoeken. Er zijn geen puzzels op te lossen, je vindt geen dagboeken, brieven of notities, geluidsopnamen of voorwerpen met een geschiedenis. Er is niets meer te doen dan sleutels zoeken en door het donker strompelen, vooral als de elektriciteit het begeeft en je het alleen met de kaarsen en je zaklamp moet doen.

Geen puzzels, bijna geen verhaal, maar een saaie, repetitieve zoektocht naar sleutels in een oerdonker huis. Kan ik dat een ander aanbevelen? Nee, als je een horror spel zoekt, speel dan liever Layers of Fear. Dat is een horror game met een geweldige sfeer, een goed verhaal en echte puzzels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013689732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1423453894}
review:
This might be the most oppressively dull attempt at horror I've ever played.

The game is entirely too long and the gameplay boils down to finding a key to open a door and find another key.  That, however, assumes you're not wandering aimlessly around the house for several minutes, wondering where you're supposed to go before the main character randomly blurts out "I heard something from <insert room here>."  What's more, the scares are all recycled ideas from other media (Amnesia and The Ring in particular), several of which are repeated no less than half-a-dozen times.

Don't waste your time or money on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109862147', 'num_games_owned': 1460, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1423053030}
review:
I don't know how this game has so many positive reviews. All you do, for thirty game days, is find keys and try them in all 200 doors of the house until you get the right one. The house becomes a maze, so by the time you're 1/3 of the way through, it becomes difficult to find doors you haven't unlocked yet. In addition to that, the house becomes completely dark at around the same time, and your flashlight batteries last about 2 minutes (I've just run out of batteries, by the way, and can't see shit). There is no indication of what you're supposed to do, so you basically have to go into each room every time after something happens, every day, to see if something is going to happen there so you can get another key to open some unknown, random door.

My main emotions have been consistent boredom and frustration rather than fear. I don't even notice half of the "scares" because it's too dark. It also seems like you lose health if you start moving the camera around when something spooky is happening (detecting your "fear"). The problem with this is that I'm not scared -- I just want to see some content to this game other than spending hours doing nothing but checking doors. Pretty much the only way I ever can tell that anything is happening is that I hear dramatic music.

I didn't finish the story, and at this point I don't give a crap about it if it means I have to spend several more hours d***ing around with the same doors. You find one note at the end of each day -- that's the story. Considering that these notes are one sentence long, I don't think there is much substance here, anyway. The notes haven't even been slightly interesting so far.

Also, the walking is slow. It's so slow that I feel like the game is majorly lagging every time I walk instead of run. You can sprint, but I think that also makes you lose health if you do it while something is happening. Obviously, we are running in this stupid game because we're scared, not because we'd prefer not to check a giant mansion of doors at a turtle's pace 30 days in a row.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128430010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1422957381}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014927344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1421024548}
review:

-Melodie,Musik und Soundeffekte sind ebenso Okay. Sch√∂n atmosph√§risch aber nach einiger Zeit langweilig

Was mich allerdings st√∂rt und nein sogar ver√§rgert.....

Fazit: Wer auf jumpscares steht, ist das spiel bei einem " Summer-Winter Sale " etwa 5-7 Euro Wert. Man wird einige male erschreckt aber nach einiger Zeit geht da die Luft raus. Wer dennoch das Game gern zuende spielt darf einfach keine STORY und KEINE Aufl√∂sung der Geschichte erwarten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006697906', 'num_games_owned': 10443, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1554902588}
review:
8/10

genre: point and click horror/mystery adventure game in 1st person

+ great atmosphere, great use of lightning and sound effects, nice graphics that fit the setting
+ gameplay is about exploring and finding keys to unlock the rooms in the house and later on on some external locations - you rely on your flashlight and matches to light candles since you have very little time at the start of each day until it gets really dark - the game is long enough, consists of 30 days, each day ends by reading a note that explains the story - simple controls and simple gameplay , it's all about exploring and getting in the mood of the game.
+ some jump scares are pretty original - the game also doesn't rely on them to frighten the player rather on the great atmosphere, i found some sound effects creepier than anything i saw so far in the game.

- story is simple and not explained in detail
- lots of backtracking makes it frustrating sometimes 
- often player looses direction until there is an event that is triggered and gives you hint on where to go

i really like the game so far, was expecting less to be honest, it's exactly the kind of indie horror/mystery game i enjoy playing. highly recommended to fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007024636', 'num_games_owned': 3608, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1450623252}
review: Door Opener Simulator: A lot of backtracking Edition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040197865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1587116536}
review:
It has a decent enough story to start with, the 'ol not much information but enough to keep you guessing as you wind your way through this haunted house.

Getting keys is what it's all about finding them hidden away like a scarey where's wally.

Graphics and the ambient sounds are great and create a good atmosphere as you wander through the house.

The sanity meter is an interesting idea and in one place I was getting quite low, turns out running round in circles makes you sane again.

Then it gets repetative, you go days and days in the games timeline not doing much and not learning much except reopening doors you have opened a dozen times in the past, it does make you drop your gaurd a little so the scares become more effective but it really does start to bore around halfway through the game.

It gets to the point where you just want to find the keys so you can finish the game and go onto something else. then you get to the end........(No spoilers)

Seriously WTF? the last level seems they sacked the writer and hired some other guy who wrote a last level and ending to something different, makes no sense at all. Apparently it's meant to be left to interpretation. Only interpretation I can come up with is they tried snorting something new when they were nearly done.

Oh an that 10.8 hours I've done, yeah the games short, but it was to be expected a good game doesn't have to be a long drawn out experience, but don't expect it to keep you going for a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077058595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1420160192}
review:
Someone sent me a text while i was playing this game and the ringer volume on my phone was maxed out, i shit myself.
Suzanne ( the name i gave to the ghost lady ) keeps psssttting me, i pssstt back at her.
Phone's wouldent stop ringing in the house, i couldn't even.
If you're debating on buying this game but you're too iffy, check out my DAY 6 video, this games deffinitly worth it, sound effects are on point! 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuVWllWVnKE&list=UUGETXX2vrz8qYh-izs4ZteA

Please don't shit yourself, as i did many times... I had to change after the recordings...
Have fun, hope this helped!


I still have 27 more days to go till i beat it... Fuck me :'(

author: {'steamid': '76561197970383523', 'num_games_owned': 736, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1420495205}
review:
Pineview Drive is all about being alone at night in a haunted mansion. Even though this sounds like an overused scenario, the game makes use of some clever scares.

If you like house exploration, almost no story and creepy atmospheres (think Gone Home), this is for you. If you hate searching for tons of keys opening tons of doors, walking in pitch black rooms and not being able to fight, this is not for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036275859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 696, 'last_played': 1416818838}
review: Ein sehr geiles Spiel zum erschrecken. Ich kann es nur weiterempfehlen :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198007380040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1665753543}
review:
This game has amazing atmosphere and is truly an awesome experience but there are things about this game that cripple it for me. For one they need to put in a REAL day/night cycle. The one in this game is fake, no other way to put it. It's also very, very, dark. When most of the game is played at night its extreamly hard to see anything infront of you. They released a prequel to this where the problem was fixed and worked very well! 

This game has great potential and shows the skill of the developers but theres problems in the gameplay that make the experience more frustrating than fun. But uniquely horrifying non the less :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198131393059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1036, 'last_played': 1675843203}
review: This is an amazing first person ghost-horror story/adventure. Though I thought at first it was a bit slow, it crept up on me like a storm and before I realized it,  I was actually frightened and obsessed with finishing. Few games have interested me as much as this one (Outlast and Slender The Arrival compare with strength of story). If you are into First Person Shooter games or lots of gore, this one isnt for you. However if you value story and substance as well an an ever increasing sense of dread, this game is for you.  Lastly, this game is long compared to some of the others I have recently played. I enjoyed it for over a week while other games I can finish in a night or so.  I hope this team makes more  games similar to this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036732067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1416952344}
review: I enjoyed this game.  It's not hard, it's not long.  It's very similar to Outlast and Amnesia: The Dark Descent.  You are basically finding keys to open doors, finding pieces of paper to end the levels, which are very short.  Batteries and matches to light your way.  The ambience is what makes the game.  Flashes, creepy noises, scary clown that has a fun horn to squeak, lol.  It's 30 days, worth playing.  I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed Amnesia and Outlast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103286841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1512249092}
review:
Nach ca. 7h Schl√ºssel suchen und einigen Schreckmomenten habe ich die 30 Tage √ºberlebt und durchgehalten.
Grafisch sehr angenehm, Wahnsinns Soundkulisse, ziemliche heftige JumpScares und eine Story die f√ºr eine Fortsetzung noch etwas offen l√§sst, eine Fortsetzung ist w√ºnschenswert!!

Die Performance ist je nachdem wie man Sie einstellt meiner Meinung nach gut, ich kann die Negativen Bewertungen nicht verstehen. Ein Tipp an alle die Probleme mit der Performance haben, Stellt mal die Schatten und die Reflektion runter, das macht einen kaum merklichen unterschied beim Spielen.

Pineview Drive arbeitet sehr mit Atmosph√§re und man muss sich wie bei allen HorrorGames auf das Spielerlebnis einlassen um das perfekte Spiele Erlebnis zu haben.

Der einzige Minuspunkt den ich geben kann liegt in der Schl√ºsselsuche, jedoch gut gel√∂st was die Problematik betrifft wenn man nicht weiterkommt, denn es gibt einen kleinen Tipp nach einer gewissen Zeit.

Ich habe von dem Spiel ein Let's Play gemacht und wenn ihr mal reinschauen wollt, dann schaut mal vorbei, w√ºrde mich freuen!

An dieser Stelle m√∂chte ich noch danke sage an VIS Games f√ºr die Entwicklung von PineView Drive, ich w√ºrde mich √ºber weitere Spiele im Horror Gerne freuen.

Ich hoffe mein Review war f√ºr euch hilfreich.

PS. Die 20 Euro f√ºr das Spiel sind gut investiert.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976202859', 'num_games_owned': 712, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1518367832}
review:
Ein Horror Survivel Erlebnis der anderen Art. In Pineview Drive schl√ºpft der Spieler in die Rolle eines namenlosen Mannes, der in ein gro√ües verlassenes Anwesen zur√ºckkehrt, um dessen Geheimnisse zu ergr√ºnden und heraus zu Finden, was mit seiner Frau geschah.

Viel Zeit hat der spieler nicht, da niemand l√§nger als 30 tage in diesen Anwesen durchgehalten hat. 

Pineview Drive Bietet trotz schw√§chelnder Grafik eine gro√üartige Sound und Musikkulisse, die besonders Angsthasen unter den Spielern einige besondere Schreckmomente beschehren kann. 

Das Spiel kann durch die Jumpscare-Events durch die Reaktion des Spieler auf der Steuerung die Angst des Spielers Messen und so den Lebensbalken des Spielers Senken. 

Ganz so, wie es versprochen wird, funktioniert dieses System leider nun auch nicht optimal. Selbst harmlose Bewegungen w√§hrend der Jumpscares wird als Lebensabzug gewertet.

Damit das System des Angst Messen optimal funktionieren k√∂nnte, h√§tte das Spiel noch andere √úberwachungsmechanismen wie z.B. das Aufzeichnen der eigenen Stimme wie das Atmen oder das Schreien bei Jumpscares, gebrauchen k√∂nnen.

Im riesigen Anwesend von Pineview Drive muss der Spieler Schl√ºssel suchen, um Jeden Tag die eine oder andere T√ºr des Anwesen zu √∂ffnen. Dabei kommt das unangeneme Repetitives Design des Spiels zum Vorschein. Der Spieler muss oft an schon besuchte Orte zur√ºckkehren und kann schonmal die Orientierung verlieren.

An und f√ºr sich kann ich jeden Horror Fan dieses Spiel empfehlen..... Ob euch Pineview Drive Angst einjagen kann oder ob es euch Kalt lassen k√∂nnte, w√ºrde ich euch raten, zuerst [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/331120/]"Passing Pineview Forest"[/url] an zu spielen, dass auf dieselben Atmosph√§re und Soundkulisse zur√ºckgreift und in der Pineview Drive Welt spielt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019572384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1458091252}
review:
No bindable keys, and the game appears to be plagued with performance issues.  The "passing pineview forest" ran perfectly for me, which uses the same engine so I don't understand how this game runs so badly.  Thinking something might be wrong with my machine, I checked the forums and people with hardware far superior to mine are having the exact same issues.

Adjusting the various graphic options doesn't appear to have any noticeable affect on performance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056818248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1416145646}
review:
In diesem Spiel ist es fast immer stockdunkel! Da bringt auch die billige Taschenlampe nicht wirklich was...Das Spiel soll erkennen, ob ich Angst habe? Ha! Da Lachen ja die H√ºhner, ich hatte gar keine Angst und hab mich in Gruselmomenten bloss umgesehen, ob nicht hinter mir auch etwas ist (zwecks Ausweichen, etc...) und das Spiel wertet das als ein Zeichen, dass ich Angst habe. An anderen Gruselstellen denke ich mir, gut, dann bleibste halt einfach mal stehen und bewegst dich gar nicht....wieder wird es als Angst gewertet...Ganz toll :-/
Also wirklich der Haupt-Minus-Punkt in dem Spiel ist die ewige Dunkelheit. Oh, tolle Grafik, noch toller als Doom 3 seinerzeit, eben weil noch dunkler....ROFL....Tolle Grafik w√ºrde man sehen k√∂nnen nun nicht nur erahnen...
Und dann das Ende....man h√§lt da also einen Monat in dem Horror-Haus aus, nur um am Ende noch mehr offene Fragen zu habe. Ich stand am Ende mit einem "H√§? WTF?" - Gesicht da und w√ºnschte mir, h√§tte ich dieses bl√∂de Spiel doch bloss nie angefangen....

Ich empfehle es euch nicht, selbst wenn es im Angebot sein sollte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048974498', 'num_games_owned': 2973, 'num_reviews': 812, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1414959737}
review:
I am currently unemployed, and sometimes worry that others may be "right" when they opine that I should NOT be waking up as late as 3 or 4pm in the afternoon.  I am glad to see that this game has cured me of any such concerns, as our main protagonist, in spite of having set himself a task of exploring a spooky haunted mansion over the course of thirty days, seemingly elects to get up no earlier than 5-5.30pm each and every day (judging by how quickly the sun goes down).  And considering how low he is on flashlight batteries and matches - indeed, did not even think to bring any with him, but as luck would have it, they are intermittently dispersed throughout said mansion - this is perhaps not the wisest of strategies.  Alas, a work ethic is a work ethic, and if he feels he is most efficient at night, I can only empathise.  Like a male prostitute, it would seem both myself and the hero of Pineview Drive do our best work after dark.  (It's a burden sometimes, but someone must be up to the task.)
 
   It would also appear that our protagonist is either an avid horror gamer himself, or failing that, someone aspiring to join the team of the Most Haunted TV series.  Because for whatever reason - "searching for clues" which have something to do with his wife, apparently - he gets up every evening, at the crack of sunset, and wanders around the house just HOPING something spooky will happen.  He searches the same rooms, over and over again, night after night, to see what spooky tricks the mansion might have to throw at him THIS time...as sooner or later, one of these spooky events is destined to lead to the finding of yet another KEY.  

   Yes...sigh...it's one of THOSE games.  

   In fact, whereas other horror and/or first-person games intersperse door-locking "puzzles" with slight variations on the theme, such as turning cranks or, well, actually solving PUZZLES perhaps, this one pretty much operates on the principle of forever looking for a key which wasn't there five seconds before said spookiness occurred.  Well, okay, sometimes it takes a smidgen longer than five seconds to acquire the key...for example, you might be standing near some windows and hear some creepy childish laughter, and look out the window to see a ghostly young lady on a set of swings outside.  So what does our humble hero do next?  Well, like we all would, he decides it's time to venture outside, into a storm, in the middle of a dark and spooky night, and check out the swings...I mean, we'd all do that, right?  Fuck waiting 'til the next day, and DAY-LIGHT...let's go outside right this second, at a time of optimum eeriness, just so we can unnecessarily scare ourselves shitless whilst obtaining yet another key (which would, presumably, still be there in the morning or afternoon if we'd only wait).  

   This "logic" is by no means the worst of the game's problems, however.  Scenarios like the one I just described, while a tad bemusing, are frankly a God-send compared to the numerous bits in the game where you simply HAVE NO FUCKING IDEA WHAT TO DO NEXT.  Fortunately, after about ten or so minutes of fruitless wandering about, your character will eventually muse something aloud like, "I don't know why, but I have a feeling I should go and check the children's room again"...which, while a bit LATE in coming, would still be something of a God-send IF WE COULD ACTUALLY REMEMBER WHERE THE CHILDREN'S ROOM IS.  If ever a game needed a map...THIS IS THAT GAME; not just to help find a room we know we're specifically looking for, but indeed to save us walking up to almost every single door in the house (which consists of several floors, AND several wings) to see which one our latest key might happen to fit...which is to say, a map could have clearly shown us which doors we HAVEN'T managed to unlock as of yet, narrowing things down a bit.  Something as simple as that could have saved THIS particular gamer, at the very least, a good few hours of unnecessary gameplay, and significantly tightened up the pacing and structure of the game while we're at it.  Wouldn't that have been nice?  Just a thought.

   Oh, and I haven't yet mentioned the game's supposedly innovative "fear-detection" system...which basically adds up to you losing a bit of "health" every time you jerk the mouse too suddenly after a scare, or keep the run button held down during such encounters, or...something like that.  Personally, I found this little feature to be almost null-and-void for the first twenty-nine chapters, as I barely ever took "damage" anyway.  That is, until Day 30, at which point the balance completely flips in the opposite direction and you can barely even MOVE FORWARD without the game interpreting said "violent" motion as sheer-and-utter-horror on your behalf.  It's a bit poorly-executed, in other words, and kinda borderline pointless even if it HAD been flawlessly implemented.  Still, I'm sure it was a nice idea on paper, a bit like the first Amnesia's almost equally pointless "sanity" system.  Full points for trying something different, though...
 
   Now, if it sounds like I'm giving this game a hard rap, don't believe a second of it.  I actually really, really liked this game.  At least until the bewildering final chapter and the ludicrously baffling final cut-scene which follows it.  Sure the game's a tad long (THIRTY DAYS?  Was it really necessary for us to endure THIRTY DAYS?!), rather repetitive, and not really all that "scary" ("spooky" is definitely the more appropriate word, as it's ultimately more bark than bite)...but other than this, if you were the kind of kid, like yours truly, who used to enjoy wandering around abandoned schoolyards and empty old houses at night in some attempt to try and scare yourself silly, this is the kind of game you can probably get behind.  But be warned:  You really DO need to be that kind of person, who enjoys EXPLORING things, and RE-EXPLORING them, and RE-EXPLORING THEM AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN, or else this is gonna bore you stupid in no time; not least of all because the occasional "hints" as to where to go next are generally few and far between.  

   In all fairness, this IS a tiny bit more than just a "walking simulator" - you can at least add "key-finding simulator", "door-unlocking simulator" and "note-finding simulator" to that list - but there isn't a great deal more to it than that.  Like any good horror game, it's really just the vaguest semblance of a "plot", ultimately serving as an excuse for the game to throw a certain number of super-atmospheric and spooky "set-pieces" your way.  If this is the kind of thing you consider entertaining, then by all means, come inside...just remember to wear your halo, though, 'cause THAT's the level of patience you're gonna need to make it all the way to the final cut scene (though if you made it all the way through this rather long-winded review, I guess you're part-way to Sainthood already)!
 
Verdict: 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130228562', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1664555043}
review:
Das Spiel ist von √ºberzeugender Grafik und erstklassiger Grusel - Atmosph√§re. Ohne Blutbad und Ekelbilder wird immer wieder f√ºr G√§nsehaut gesorgt. Das Haus ist hervorragend gestaltet. Alles ist stimmig und passend. Die Garderoben, die Wandbilder, die Beleuchtung. Man riecht f√∂rmlich das alte Holz der knarzenden Treppen.
Jedoch wird es √ºber die vielen Level dann doch manchmal etwas fade: Schl√ºssel suchen. Dann die T√ºr suchen, die zu dem Schl√ºssel passt, dann den Brief finden. Dies zieht sich √ºber die meisten Tage  (Level) des Spiels und sollte etwas h√§ufiger durch andere Aufgaben und/oder Ereignisse unterbrochen werden, z-B. √§hnlich wie in Tag 30. 
Aber es lohnt sich dranzubleiben. Die Gruseleffekte nehmen zu und legen auch an Qualit√§t zu. Die Schattenspiele sind einzigartig.
Die Horror-Atmosph√§re st√ºtzt sich zum gr√∂ssten Teil auf Soundeffekte. Auch wenn man es erst nicht glauben mag, aber es wurde so brilliant umgesetzt, dass es funktioniert. 
Da man im Laufe des Spiels das Haus Zimmer f√ºr Zimmer, Korridor f√ºr Korridor, Trackt f√ºr Trackt erforscht, wird es mit der Zeit un√ºbersichtlich und man kann sich verlaufen. Jedoch wird es nicht so √ºbertrieben schlimm, dass man nur noch umherirrt. Es ist also noch zu schaffen, einen ungef√§hren √úberblick zu behalten.
Fazit: Tolles Spiel mit Grusel ohne Blutbad und Gewalt. Auch wenn man im Mittel etwas durchhalten muss und dranbleiben muss: Es lohnt sich. Pr√§dikat: Empfehlenswert.
Letsplayer: Es ist darauf zu achten, dass die Zuschauer die Soundatmosph√§re mitbekommen und das Spiel sollte nicht √ºbermoderiert, also plattgequatscht werden.
2. September 2014 - Julia LetsPlays

author: {'steamid': '76561198055239323', 'num_games_owned': 1201, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1581787701}
review:
Durch ein kleines LetsPlay und durch einen Steamfreund sowies einem kleinen Artikel wo drin stand, das das Spiel auf den Spieler reagiert, also seine Aktionen usw und somit Gruseliger wird, bin ich hellh√∂rig geworden!

Ja ich ahbe "nur" knapp 2 st mit dem Spiel verbracht, habe es gestreamed und somit die 2st durchgezogen bis tag 6!

Am Titelbildschirm angekommen war ich noch sehr angetan da selbst dieser einen kleinen Schockeffekt beinhaltet! Die Idee an sich fande ich auch klasse und musste es einfach haben in der Hoffnung das ich mich auch mal wieder erschrecken w√ºrde! Ich bin anscheinend sauviel gewohnt denn nach den ersten 1-2 Scares war bei mir der Ofen fast aus! Die Schocks sind an f√ºr sich relativ originel√∂ (hat man aber schon in vielen Filmen gesehen) und diese schocken einfach nach gewisser zeit kaum noch! Es kommen immerwieder die selben Sounds, ger√§usche etc! Wie egsagt, das alles ist super ghemacht und Athmosph√§risch aber verfehlt zumindest bei mir jetzt schon die Wirkung! Spoilern m√∂chte ich nicht weiter denn jetzt kommt der gr√∂√üte Minuspunkt! das Spielprinzip!

In einem Raum aufwachen, ger√§usch h√∂ren, hingehen, zwischendurch ein paar Schritte und Kinderlachen, Schl√ºssel Finden, Licht an, Schl√ºssel finden, Licht aus, Schl√ºssel finden, Kerzen an, Schl√ºssel finden, Kerze aus...ach und ...s
Schl√ºssel finden! Aber das Schlimmste ist das f√ºr jede T√ºr ein Schl√ºssel ben√∂tigt wird, das Haus wird immer Gr√∂√üer was die R√§ume angeht und man ist zu 90% nur am Rennen unm die T√ºr zu finden zu der der Schl√ºssel geh√∂rt und das nervt echt jetzt schon Tierichst! 

sehr Schade drum! Nehm es mir nicht √ºbel, das Spiel ist nicht Schlecht, hatt aber Potenzial, ist aber nun leider schon fertig!

Leute die nix gewohnt sind und sich docvh leicht erschrecken werden sicher ihren Spa√ü haben, aber nicht f√ºr 20euro!

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198009893503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1616176318}
review:
So I was looking at this game for quite a few days considering if I was gonna buy it or not, and the only thing that kept me from actually getting it was all the negative reviews that was posted on it.

I did however decide to get it and see what the game had to offer and by now I have put quite a few hours into the game. I am gonna be completely honest and neutral when I say that this game has received more thumbs down in the review section on Steam that it deserved. 

Yes the story in the game is not great and it does leave you with a lot of questions in regard to why you are staying inside a haunted house searching for your wife that went missing 20 years ago. And to be honest if I had not read the game description before playing I would never have guessed the story at all.

HOWEVER!
This game is not ment to be played for its story. The game itself has an amazing atmosphere that makes you aware of your surroundings and most of time it is not the scares, but the atmosphere itself that keeps you coming back.

Don't get me wrong, the game does have scary elements and they are VERY well placed in the game. The scares are unpredictable and suprises you every step of the way and the best of all; "The scares are awesome and not cheap!".
And not to mention that freaking ***** that makes me too scared to pass him every time a need to go through a certain hallway...

BUT BE WARNED!
The story is not the only bad thing about the game because there are quite a few other things that could definitely get improved which I will go over.

First of all as soon as I started playing this game I noticed my FPS dropped constantly between 24-34 FPS on highest quality while I was recording with my screen recorder (should probably mention that screen recorders does tend to decrease the FPS a bit when active). I did need to tinger a bit with the quality settings before i could get a 33-44 FPS.
I can play Crysis 3 with 3 times better FPS on ultra settings, and trust me, this is not a hardware problem!
My PC has a:
 - i7 4770k core processor
 - GeForce GTX 780 graphics card
 - 16GB RAM

The second issue I found with the actual gameplay itself is the objectives inside the game. A lot of people reviewing this title is calling it a "Open door simulator" and they are definitely not wrong. The entire gameplay is you finding keys so you can unlock new doors that allows you to start a new day.

But don't get discouraged, even with these faults I still believe this is a great game and if you are looking for a horror game that simulates a haunted house this is definitely a game worth getting. The whole time I was sucked into it and because of the variety of the scares I never felt each scare was remotely similar to eachother. If you are willing to go through the process of collecting keys then this game will definitely be worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022253437', 'num_games_owned': 3102, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1419070900}
review:
JAWOOOOOHHHHLLLL!

Erst einmal, hier k√∂nnt ihr euch ein Video ansehen, wo Ihr schon etwas mehr seht was ich nun meinen werde!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S8KMr1ETtKw

Nun aber zu der "Kaufempfehlung":

Das Spiel hat zwar seine Macken ist aber sehr Stimmig und Atmosph√§risch. Wie ich in einigen meiner Videos schon Sagte ist einige Prozentual gehalten welches dem Spiel erm√∂glicht mehr Grusel Stimmung zu erhalten. (Es gibt aber auch Schl√ºssel Elemente die immer Gleich aufgebaut sind!)
In jedem einzelnen Tag welches man in diesem Haus beschreiten muss und davon gibt es ganze 30 an der Zahl, passiert immer was neues immer was Aufregenderes und immer was Gruseligeres.
Man sollte sich das Spiel mal selber angucken und nicht immer gleich auf Reviews z√§hlen, denn wie Jeder von uns Gamern wei√ü... Ein Spiel wirkt immer anders.

Pro/Contra Liste: 

Positiv:
- Sehr gruselige bedr√ºckende Atmosph√§re 
- Gute Schockeffekt
- Grandiose Klangkulisse
- Grafik ist nicht schlecht, h√§tte aber auch besser sein k√∂nnen. Die Schatten Effekte sind aber sehr gut gemacht und auch Stimmig.


Negativ:
- Teilweise sehr Erm√ºdend
- Teilweise wei√ü man gar nicht wo man hin muss, dann ist warten angesagt bis der Protagonist dir eine Hilfe gibt, oder du musst jeden Tag aufs neue jeden schon besuchten Raum neu erkunden.. das ist teilweise sehr Nervt√∂tend!


Wie ich schon Sagte: Das Spiel ist nicht f√ºr jeden etwas, dennoch sollte man es sich mal Angucken! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198042718931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1478145126}
review:
Auf Empfehlung eines Mitmenschen dieses Planeten und auf gro√üz√ºgige Spende eines anderen Menschen hin, nahm ich mir dieses Spiel zur Brust. Ich sah den Titelbildschirm. Ich war entz√ºckt. Die Melodie, die im Hintergrund spielte, war sehr angenehm und atmosph√§risch. Das Gesicht im Fenster und dieser Effekt, der den Titelbildschirm aussehen l√§sst wie in einem alten Film vermitteln einen guten ersten Eindruck.

Meine lieben Mitb√ºrger und Mitb√ºrgerinnen: Ich habe Ihnen so eben den besten Teil des Spiels, so gut ich konnte, beschrieben. Ja, Sie haben richtig geh√∂rt. Der Titelbildschirm ist das Beste, was das Spiel zu bieten hat.

Man startet das Spiel. Eine Cutscene spielt. Sie ist schelcht. Sie ist un√ºbersichtlich. Man hat keine Ahnung, was passiert. Man steht vor einem Haus. Was tun? Man geht zum Eingang, er ist verschlossen. Was passiert? Das erste R√§tsel des Spiels kommt zum Tragen. Finden sie den Schl√ºssel! Nun wird der gemeine Homo sapiens denken: "Oha, wo k√∂nnte dieser Schl√ºssel sein? Ist er vllt irgendwo in einem Geb√ºsch? Vllt. in einem Briefkasten?" NEIN. Sie drehen sich um 180¬∞ nach Hinten und da ist der ver ... maledeite Schl√ºssel. Auf dem Boden ... er l√§chelt sie f√∂rmlich an. Denn er wei√ü, dass er einer von Hunderten seiner Art ist, die Ihnen im Laufe des Spiels irgendwann f√∂rmlich aus dem Ar*ch kriechen werden. So gehen sie nun dahin und √∂ffnen das Tor. Der Protagonist wird ihnen innerhalb von vier kurzen S√§tzen seine Gedankenwelt mitteilen, die ungef√§hr so interessant ist wie dem Gras beim Wachsen zuzusehen. Sie werden schnell merken, dass Spiel sofort an Fahrt aufnimmt. Denn nun sehen sie sich vor der Aufgabe: "Wie komme ich denn nun in dieses Haus rein?" Sie denken sich erstmal: "Ne, der Vordereingang kann's nicht sein, das hier ist ja ein Horrorspiel, das w√§re zu einfach" und so schauen sie sich vielleicht erstmal ein wenig um, werden hinter dem Haus eine Vogelscheuche bemerken, die im Laufe des Spieles einen unglaublich schlechten Job machen wird, die Kr√§hen vom Grundst√ºck fernzuhalten und landen letzten Endes doch beim Haupteingang. Sie versuchen diesen zu √∂ffnen und werden mit Freuden feststellen, dass dieser verschlossen ist. "Hahah, ich hatte recht, der Haupteingang w√§re zu offensichtlich gewesen" So m√ºssen sie also nun den Schl√ºs .... oh warte, er ist 2 cm neben dem ve****ten sch***drecks Haupteingang. Sie betreten das Haus. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt k√∂nnte man sich noch denken, dass das Spiel gruselig werden wird. (spoiler: Pustekuchen) Sie sehen sich etwas um, merken dass alle T√ºren verschlossen sind, obwohl laut Aussage des Protagonisten in den letzten Jahren durchaus Leute in diesem Haus gelebt haben, aber keine Sorge, innerhalb des Hauses gibt es f√ºr jede T√ºr einen dazugeh√∂rigen Schl√ºssel, der jeweils am anderen Ende des Hauses zu finden ist. Sie laufen etwas umher, finden einen Schl√ºssel, probieren diesen Schl√ºssel an den 10 verschlossenen T√ºren, an denen sie schon vorbeigekommen sind aus, in eine wird er reinpassen, da finden sie einen neuen Schl√ºssel, den sie an den restlichen 9 T√ºren, die noch verbleiben ausprobieren bis sie die Richtige gefunden haben. In jenem Raum finden sie dann ... man m√∂ge es kaum glauben ... EINE TASCHENLAMPE ... und einen Schl√ºssel .... f√ºr eine T√ºre ... irgendwo ... in diesem Haus ... Nach einer Weile wird es dunkel und total creepy ... sie werden merken, sie k√∂nnen sich mit Hilfe der Taschenlampe, Kerzen und Lichtschaltern Lichtquellen erschaffen, die jeglichen Gesetzen der Physik widersprechen.   Sie durchsuchen also alle R√§ume nach Hinweisen, die der Protagonist sucht und merken nach dreimaligem Durchsuchen der R√§ume, dass da nix ist. Doch pl√∂tzlich nach 15 Minuten desselben Ablaufs hat sich pl√∂tzlich ein Raum ge√§ndert, St√ºhle stehen anders da und da ist ein Zettel. Er liest den Zettel, auf dem 5 W√∂rter stehen und der Tag endet.

SO UNGEF√ÑHR IST DANN JEDER TAG.
Ich m√∂chte an dieser Stelle nicht viel Spoilern, ich gebe ihnen nur noch kurz meine Highlights zu diesem Spiel bekannt.

- Gleich neben dem Schlafzimmer gibt es eine Abstellkammer, die einfach mal auf alles, was sie in Physik gelernt haben, schei√üt. In dieser Abstellkammer gibt es kein Fenster. Es gibt eine Lampe, die normalerweise aus ist. Es gibt absolut keine Lichtquelle, in diesem Raum, sofern man jene Lampe nicht anmacht. Wenn man in diesem Raum steht und die T√ºre zu ist, dann ist der Raum trotzdem vollkommen erhellt. Hat jemand dieses Spiel jemals testgespielt? Ich meine ... wie kann einem sowas nicht auffallen?

- Jeglicher Horror in diesem Spiel besteht aus billigst inszenierten Jumpscares. Mein pers√∂nlicher Favorit war recht am Anfang. Es ist ein zwei-dimensionales, kleines Jpeg, das schlichtweg, vermutlich per Paint, vergr√∂√üert wurde und dabei noch nicht mal scharf gemacht wurde. Es springen einem wortw√∂rtlich 2D-Pixel ins Gesicht. 3spooky5me

- Jeder Tag besteht daraus: Was tun? Ich habe keinerlei Hinweis darauf, was ich wo zu tun habe. Ich laufe 10 Minuten durch die Gegend, ab und an "erschreckt" mich einer dieser legend√§ren Jumpscares und dann entscheidet sich der Protagonist dazu, weil ihm schon so stinklangweilig von diesem Spiel wurde, einem zu sagen, wo man nachschauen sollte. Und was mich immer wieder fasziniert hat ist die Pr√§zesion des Wissens vom Protagonisten. "Hm ... vllt. sollte ich im Badezimmer des 2. Stockwerks des Hauptrakts nachschauen, ob sich eine M√∂we darin verirrt hat und gerade mit aller Urgewalt in die Badewanne abseilt." Tja und kurzer Hand entscheidet man sich dann dazu, in besagtem Badezimmer nachzusehen und siehe da: Die M√∂we ist beim Versuch des Abseilens gestorben und hinterlie√ü dabei einen Schl√ºssel. Und nun kommen wir zum 2. gro√üen Gimmick dieses Spiels: Wo passt der Schl√ºssel? Sie haben nun den Schl√ºssel aus dem Darmtrakt einer M√∂we entfernt und d√ºrfen sich durch die restlichen 20000000000 T√ºren durchk√§mpfen, bis sie die Richtige gefunden haben, DIE NAT√úRLICH IMMER DIE LETZTE IST, DIE SIE PROBIEREN. 

- Das Ende ist schlichtweg ... wie kann man es sagen, ohne den Entwickler so sehr zu beleidigen, als dass ich mit einer Geldstrafe rechnen m√ºsste ... d√ºrftig ... Es erkl√§rt nichts ... es ist schlecht ... es ist frustierend.

Ich sitze schon eine halbe Stunde an diesem Review. Ich k√∂nnten noch 2 Stunden so weiter machen. Ich k√∂nnte jede Einzelheit aufsagen, die mit diesem Spiel nicht stimmt. Aber ich lasse es lieber, da das hier eh kein Mensch lesen wird. Ich m√∂chte nur als Fazit sagen: 20‚Ç¨ f√ºr dieses Spiel sind eine absolute Unversch√§mtheit. Gerade mal gratis w√§re dieses Spiel "ok" gewesen. Und auch nicht mehr. Der einzige Mensch, der an diesem Spiel gearbeitet hat, der sich am Ende des Tages nicht f√ºr seine Existenz sch√§men m√ºsste, ist derjenige, der f√ºr den Sound verantwortlich ist. Der Sound ist okay. Die Musik ist ganz nett und die Ger√§usche sind halbwegs passend. 

Ich m√∂chte eben als Vergleich das Spiel "The Cat Lady" anbringen. F√ºr jenes Spiel war vermutlich ein wesentlich geringeres Budget vorhanden. Und trotzdem wurde mit wenig Mitteln ein kleines Meisterwerk erschaffen, das kaum Aufmerksamkeit bekommen hat und das man f√ºr 9‚Ç¨ auf Steam bekommen kann, w√§hrend man f√ºr diese Beleidigung eines Horrorspiels 20‚Ç¨ berappen soll. 

Ich wei√ü, keiner zwingt irgendjemanden dieses Spiel zu spielen und meine Bewertung klingt wie von einem 12-j√§hrigen, w√ºtenden Kind geschrieben, aber f√ºr alle, die sich nicht bei jedem kleinsten, billigen Jumpscare in die Hose machen wird dieses Spiel eine massive Entt√§uschung √ºber alle Ma√üen sein. 

Gesamtwertung: 1/10, auch nur, weil mir der Mensch leid tut, der f√ºr den Sound verantwortlich ist. Denn der hat zumindest ein bisschen was drauf und ist f√ºr sein Leben damit gestraft, bei diesem Spiel mitgewirkt zu haben.

Jeder Tag zwingt einen dazu weiter in die Gem√§uer des Pineview anwesens vorzudringen und somit auch neuen Foltern f√ºr den Verstand.
Auch muss man das Angstsystem f√ºr sich entdecken, denn was genau als erschrecken gilt und was nicht, l√§sst das Spiel bewusst im Verborgenen. So kommt zus√§tzlich zum Schock auch noch etwas zus√§tzliche Schwierigkeit hinzu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031826746', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1407502734}
review:
If you want to see it as a demo of a new horror game mechanism, Pineview Drive is great and could definitely be worth a try. If you're a veteran horror fan and will do anything for a few seconds of real in-game fear, I promise you that you'll get your scares in the first few hours--that alone might be worth the $15 price tag. But as a stand-alone game, judged against other indie horror games out there, Pineview Drive is probably not worth playing. The first few nail-biting days in the mansion had me really optimistic about what was coming next. But the tedious gameplay (plan to walk through pretty every room in the house, multiple times, every day, looking for keys or journal entries), the overused scares, and the lack of a compelling story quickly drained both fear and enjoyment from my experience. The developers themselves defend the lack of story, posting the following in the Steam forums:

[quote=aegsds]We are sorry, but this game don¬¥t has a typical ending like "ok look this is the end of the story now and everything was clear from the beginning". The game wants you to come up with own ideas of what really happend.[/quote]

The problem with a philosophy like this is that it only makes sense if there is enough material in the game for the player to come up with their own version of events (think Home or even Gone Home). This haunted house has little personality of its own, and feels more like being in an amusement park ride than in an actual place with a history. For example, there was one random event that had my character trapped in a room full of clocks, and the ticking seemed to be driving him insane. All the clocks were set to 5:00. Did something happen at 5:00? Is that when I could have killed my wife, or when...something happened? No, it turns out that it was just another random scare, and the clocks were only set to 5:00 because that's where they stall at the end of each day. And I never did find out what my character had done or what happened to him. The events at the end of the game didn't reveal anything.

For an example in contrast: in haunted-house games like Amnesia (both Frictional's original and thechineseroom's sequel), not only is there a coherent story, there are general themes that add to your experience of the environments. Exploitation, torture, loss of children, surveillance, monstrous industry...the simple events of the game are darkly colored by the way your imagination slowly mulls over these ideas as you play. You won't find any deep story elements like that in Pineview Drive. The scary sound is just a scary sound, the scary doll is just a scary doll, and you can be scared or not be scared in the moment--but this isn't a game where you take the fear with you, a game that leaves you lying awake at night, unable to move on to pleasant dreams.

So much wasted potential in this game, which could have been something memorable with an overhaul of the key-hunting gameplay and some love from a writer who cares about telling a good story. I hope the developers learn from this experience and continue to work with their fear mechanic, because it does have a lot of potential. (However, it's also currently imbalanced, making the last day of the game almost impossible to complete.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198121494479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1407431109}
review:
My first impression of the game and its concept was good. It's rare that a game has made me jump in my seat more than once, and at least for me this game delivered that. At first I enjoyed the environment and didn't overly mind the game mechanics.

Unfortunately, there are a few negative aspects to the game that result in the kind of frustration that can make one give up and quit. I did just that, on day 14 in-game. I left when the game turned into "Door Unlocking in the Dark Simulator".	

1. The complete lack of lighting. Candlelight is useless in the corridors, as they don't light up more than a 2-foot radius. You can't see anything by them, their purpose is limited to a marker as a point of reference to run toward. The flashlight batteries don't last long enough, which was the deal-breaker that made me walk away as an unsatisfied customer. Once the flashlight runs out, it becomes physically impossible to progress in the game. I'm on a MacBook Pro Retina, and no combination of screen brightness or in-game brightness setting allows me to see even one foot in front of me. I'm literally locked in a black screen with no idea if I'm standing in front of a door or a wall. This ruined the entire game - the flashlight should be infinitely powered, simple as that. With the flashlight it's still dark enough to be spooky, but you can at least see where you're going.

2. Too many doors with no in-game tracking of what is going on. Not all gamers have great spacial awareness and the fantastic memory required to remember exactly which doors are still locked, let alone where every single door leads. Once the house really begins to open up around day 10, I completely lost all sense of the house's layout and the ability to navigate. You would think that running around the layout over and over again would ingrain the map in your mind, but at least for me this was not the case - it's just too much all at once to keep track of. Bare minimum, a door should be visibly marked as either locked or unlocked without having to try to open it. Even better, add an in-game map that shows the layout as well as the status of all doors.

3. I have never, ever - ever! - played a game where you had to permanently hold down a key on the keyboard in order to play. The character's walking speed is abysmal - it is mandatory to hold down SHIFT every second you play to get the character to "run" (aka, walk at a normal pace). There should at least be a setting to inverse the walk/run speeds (ie: option to make character fast by default, hold shift to walk).

4. Far too often, there is absolutely no clue given about where you should look next. You wander around the entire house checking nearly every room until your character finally gives in and states something like "I think I heard water running in the bathroom", when there was never an auditory cue of running water. Same for "noises from the chess room", and a few others. Overall, I think this game would have benefited a lot from a little more leading of the story, rather than expecting us to run around constantly looking for that "one thing" happening somewhere in the house. I think the developer probably considers this the "mystery" element to the game, having to hunt through every room over and over again. The problem is it isn't fun, and only serves to stretch out game play.

I'd say this game would be good for gamers who have unlimited patience, those who have never quit a game out of frustration after being expected to do the same thing over and over again with very little progress. You also need to be comfortable playing in a completely dark environment (not just dark, but pitch black), where the only visual aid you get is a red outline around actionable objects.

I wish I could praise this game for being clever and unique, but I paid $20 and made it less than halfway through the game. At that point, I ran out of flashlight batteries and was left with a game where I have a black screen and red outlines around doorknobs and candlesticks. Not my idea of a good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118539187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1407369890}
review:
A quite elaborate review for Pineview Drive, TL:DR at the bottom. Enjoy!

Pineview Drive provides an interesting approach on the whole horror scenario, although the setting is quite classic: 

There is this huge mansion, strange stuff is going on there, no one knows exactly what it is just that nobody survived longer than 30 days. And now it's up to you to enter the house, solve the mystery and stay alive until day 30 and beyond...

The MechaniX (minor spoilers!):
The biggest asset of Pineview Drive is, as you might already know, the 'Punished for Panic' mechanic, that actually works quite nice especially since it also provides a 'Reward for Relax' function. This means, the game will try to scare you, and the further you get into it, the more creative it gets. If you get scared or shocked, you will lose lifeforce (basically hitpoints) and the game turns the screw a little tighter on you. Playing in total darkness with a headphone is definitely not recommended for the faint hearted player. On the other hand, if you remain calm, you will slowly regenerate and your character will relax.

The PlayZ:
The gameplay revolves around finding keys, unlocking rooms and gathering small bits of information about the mystery engulfing this cursed building. Whenever you find another clue the game advances to the next day and saves your progress. Finding those keys can be quite time consuming and will require a lot of backtracking. A good sense of direction and orientation is more than helpful, since there will be no minimap to guide you. 

Apart from keys you will also find matches and batteries to help you, since you will be playing mostly at night, and the game provides a nice variety of light sources (see The TechniX). The game also offers a helpful clue-system that points you in the general direction whenever you are completely lost or running into the utterly wrong direction. These clues come in the form of your character dropping a line in the form of 'Didn't I xxxxx something in that xxxxx place?' and will help you finding the next objective. 

Keeping a watchful eye on your surroundings to actually find the objectives is up to you, of course, although objects are highlighted to make them easier to spot, once you are close.

The TechniX:
My first impression on the technical performance were slightly disappointing, since the game seems to have framerate issues due to its programming. Cranking all details up to max might result in a laggy performance, even if you sport a powerful system. Also the textures are not as High-Res as you might be used from other triple-A titles and some objects definitely look a bit cheaply designed. The overall graphic appearance is still solid, and I have seen Indie-Games that looked far worse (not counting the ones that actually want to have a 8/16-Bit look).

What the graphic engine does great is the light-sourcing! 
Since you will be surrounded by semi-darkness most of the game, the use of lightsources and options plays an important part in your gameplay. A single, bright source of light will cast extreme shadows, and I have oftend found myself in a situation, where a single flickering candle is rather emphasizing the darkness, then keeping it at bay. Sometimes the moonlight and weather-effects are more than enough light to get around, instead of using the lightswitch and plunging half a room  in pitchblack darkness.

So what about the audios?
This is where Pineview Drive really shines. From heavy breathing to creaking floortiles, the developers sure know how to use sound to make you feel uneasy! A creepy background soundtrack also helps to create the tensed athmosphere that empowers the basic 'don't get scared'-catch of the game.

And the controls?
Using the mouse to look around while moving with your standard WASD is something you should be used to, although I miss an option to rebind the keys and most of all an 'always run' option, since holding down the left shift-key for hours can be a pain in the ... especially since the movement without shift is dreadfully slow and rarely neccessary. There is also E to use/pickup stuff, F-lashlight on/off and R-eload batteries.

TL:DR - The ConclusionZ: 
Pineview Drive is a nice House of Horrors game, that focusses on athmosphere instead of throwing zombies and skeletons at you. Keeping calm in surprise-situations is key to surviving the 30 day plot that will take around 8-9 hours to beat. 

The graphic is not the finest and slightly Low-Res in places, although the lightsourcing and weather effects are solid work. Some optimization might be needed/patched to solve the framerate issues. Therefore the soundeffects are nice and scary.

Approx. 20‚Ç¨ at fullprice might be bit overpriced for some, but getting it on a steam-sale should be worth your money.

Hope this review helped you in your decision, feedback is much appreciated.
Don't get scared!
Shendril
